div.head: INTRODUCTION
div.p: Both volumes of the SCANDINAVIAN CLASSICS selected to appear in 1916 are by natives of Iceland . They belong , however , to periods of time and to modes of writing remote from each other . Snorri Sturluson , the greatest of Icelandic historians , was born in 1179 . His Prose Edda , the companion-piece of the present volume , is a Christian 's account of Old Norse myths and poetic conceptions thus happily preserved as they were about to pass into oblivion . More than seven hundred years separate Jóhann Sigurjónsson from Snorri , and his work is in dramatic , not saga form . But even as in outward appearance modern Iceland is not unlike ancient Iceland , so the Icelandic writers of the present have marked kinship with the past . Despite many centuries of relative neglect , the old traditions lived on , cherished by scholars , until now , at the beginning of the twentieth century , the Icelandic mind appears to be again renascent and creative . Einar Jónsson , the sculptor , has his counterpart in the domain of letters in such recent writers as Jónas Jónasson , Emar Hjörleifsson , Gudmundur Magnússon , Jónas Gudlaugsson , Gunnar Gunnarson , and Gudmundur Kamban , while every important fjord and valley can claim its own poet or novelist . As yet , the most distinguished performance of these younger authors is the play printed in this volume , Eyvind of the Hills ( Bjærg-Ejvind og hans Hustru ) , by Jóhann Sigurjónsson . Among literary phenomena Eyvind of the Hills is a surprise , almost as though Iceland woke to find her naked mountains clothed in forest in a night .

Let Sigurjónsson tell his life story in his own words :[ 1 ] “ I was born June 19 , 1880 , on a large farm in the northern part of Iceland . Our household numbered about twenty people . A broad stream , well stocked with salmon ; on both sides of the river , rocks where thousands of eider-ducks had their nests ; a view out over the Atlantic with high cliffs where sea-birds lived ; lava-fields with unusual flowers ; and in the distance blue mountains ; such was the theatre where I acted my childhood pieces and where I wrote my first poems .
div.note: A letter dated November 7 , 1912 , to M. Leon Pineau , published in La Revue ( Paris ) , July 1 , 1914 .
div.p: “ When fourteen years old , I was sent to school at Reykjavik ; but after pocketing the diploma of the upper class , my longing led me down to Copenhagen , where I chose the study of veterinary science . For three years I worked zealously at my studies and took all the preliminary examinations required , until suddenly I burned my ships and resolutely threw myself into the work of a playwright . At first one difficulty piled up after another . To begin with , I had to write in a language not my own . And then , what knowledge I had of human nature was limited to a most incomplete knowledge of myself and of a few college chums of my own age . Besides , it was not long before I had to concern myself about mere bread and butter .

“ My first victory was an appreciative letter from Björnstjerne Björnson , wherein he promised warmly to recommend me to Gyldendal 's , the great publishing house , which subsequently published my first play , Dr. Rung .

titlePage.docImprint: “ My second victory was the acceptance by the Dagmar Theatre of The Hraun Farm . After the sometime directors of that theatre resigned , my play passed into the control of the Royal Theatre . Finally , I made my stage debut with Eyvind of the Hills , which was received with much enthusiasm both by press and public . “ In order to give as much actuality as possible to this drama , I traversed Iceland on foot from north to south and saw the places high up in the wild mountain waste where Eyvind lived with his wife . In my little garret in Copenhagen I had learned by my own experience the agony of loneliness . ” Sigurjónsson 's first drama , Dr. Rung , was written in Danish and published in1905. This tragedy presents a young Copenhagen physician , Harold Rung , who is endeavoring to find a specific against tuberculosis . In order to test the effect of his serum , he decides to inoculate himself with the disease , and the pleading of Vilda , who loves him , fails to shake him from his purpose . The remedy proves a failure ; the young scientist goes mad , giving Vilda poisoned grapes . The Hraun Farm was published in Icelandic in1908( Bóndinn á Hrauni ) , and in Danish in1912( Gaarden Hraun ) . In rewriting the play for the Copenhagen stage , Sigurjónsson gave it a happy ending , thus changing a tragedy into a pleasant dramatic idyl of contemporary country life in Iceland . It is the familiar Scandinavian theme of the struggle of human love with love of the homestead . An old farmer , Sveinungi , is a veritable patriarch living at the edge of the “ hraun , ” the lava-field . His only daughter , Ljot , he has destined for a sturdy neighbor 's son , who will keep up the estate . But the girl falls in love with a young geologist and arouses her father 's wrath , until the play ends with a scene in which Sveinungi is won over by Jorunn , his persuasive wife . The action is interrupted by an earthquake . The dialogue is well maintained and rises to heights of lyrical splendor . In point of dramatic effectiveness , The Hraun Farm may be regarded as only a preliminary study compared to the next play , but its picture of pastoral Iceland makes it a fitting companion-piece to the greater drama in the present volume . All other work of Sigurjónsson and the younger Icelandic dramatists pales beside Eyvind of the Hills , written in Danish and published in1911.[ 2 ]The high sky of dramatic vision , the simple nobility of the characters portrayed , and the poetry of exalted passion raise above the ordinary this stern tragedy of natural lives in the wilderness . Eyvind is a man of heroic mould , who was forced by circumstances and hunger to the state of a common thief . When outlawed , he fled to the mountains . Seeking human companionship , he now descends into a valley where his identity is unknown and takes service with Halla , a rich young widow . She learns of his disguise only to fall in love with his real character . Persecuted by her brother-in-law , who wishes to marry her , and possessed by a great love , she insists on sharing the outlaw 's lot and escapes with him to his old haunt in the mountains . Here they have two children , but she is obliged to sacrifice them both in turn , and to flee ever farther away . The last act finds the outlaw and his wife facing each other in a lonely hut , in the midst of a snowstorm which has shut off every avenue of sustenance . Although the beautiful reality of love is there , they are tormented by hunger and utter need into doubts and mutual reproaches , and at last seek death in the snow . [ Footnote 2 : The English translation combines features of the original edition and a revised version printed in1913. The play appeared also in Icelandic ( Fjalla-Eyvindur ) in1912. ] According to the historical facts upon which the story is based , a stray horse found its way to the hut of the starving couple , and so their lives were saved . Sigurjónsson used this ending when he rewrote the last scenes of the fourth act for Fru Dybvad , who played the part of Halla in Copenhagen , concluding with Halla 's exclamation : “ So there is then a God ! ” With Eyvind , as with The Hraun Farm , we can thus take our choice of two endings . The Wish ( Önsket ) , Sigurjónsson 's latest play , was published in1915. Gloomy and terrible , but strong and restrained , it is built on a theme of seduction , remorse , and forgiveness in death , woven about the legendary figure of Galdra-Loftur , who lived in Iceland at the beginning of the eighteenth century . It ends with an intensely dramatic scene in the old cathedral church at Hólar . In addition to these four plays , Sigurjónsson has also written some beautiful verse . In Mrs. Schanche , Sigurjónsson has a translator well fitted by artistic family traditions for the task . Herself of Norwegian descent , she has been for upward of thirty years a resident ofPhiladelphia. She has interpreted the pure idiom of Sigurjónsson 's dialogue with real dramatic perception . In editing the volume the Publication Committee has had the valuable assistance of Hanna Astrup Larsen .

docTitle.titlePart: Georg Brandes , the veteran Danish critic , though not given to over optimism , has recognized Sigurjónsson 's distinction , and the Icelander is acclaimed by the public who best know Ibsen and Strindberg , in Copenhagen , Stockholm , and Christiania . Eyvind has been successful also on the German stage . “ Poetic talent of high order , ” says Brandes , “ manifests itself in this new drama , with its seriousness , rugged force , and strong feeling . Few leading characters , but these with a most intense inner life ; courage to confront the actual , and exceptional skill to depict it ; material fully mastered and a corresponding confident style ! ” And the French critic , Leon Pineau , concludes a long account of Sigurjónsson 's production with the following estimate of Eyvind of the Hills : “ In this drama there is no haze of fantasy , no bold and startling thesis , not even a new theory of art — nothing but poetry ; not the poetry of charming and fallacious words , not that of lulling rhythm , nor of dazzling imagery which causes forgetfulness , but the sublimely powerful poetry which creates being of flesh and blood like ourselves — to whom Jóhann Sigurjónsson has given of his own soul . ” Written by the author in a language not his by birth , this rock-ribbed tragedy of the strong and simple passions of Iceland lends itself peculiarly to international interpretation . It is with some curiosity , therefore , as well as satisfaction , that we introduce to English readers a young representative of the renaissance of Icelandic literature . How will he be judged by our countrymen , and what will be his place , if any , upon the American stage ? H. G. L .
EYVIND OF THE HILLS [ Bjærg-Ejvind og Hans Hustru ] A DRAMA IN FOUR ACTS

set.p: The action takes place in Iceland in the middle of the eighteenth century . The story of the two principal characters is founded an historical events . Halla 's nature is moulded on a Danish woman 's soul .

div.head: ACT I

stage.stage: A “ badstofa ” or servants ’ hall . Along each side-wall , a row of bedsteads with bright coverlets of knitted wool . Between the bedsteads , a narrow passageway . On the right , the entrance , which is reached by a staircase . On the left , opposite the entrance , a dormer-window with panes of bladder . On the right , over the bedsteads , a similar window . Long green blades of grass are visible through the panes . In the centre back a door opens into Halla 's bed-chamber , which is separated from the “ badstofa ” by a thin board partition . A small table-leaf is attached by hinges to the partition . A copper train-oil lamp is fastened in the doorcase . Over the nearest bedsteads a cross-beam runs at a man 's height from the floor ; from this to the roof-tree is half of a man 's height . Under the window stands a painted chest . Carved wooden boxes are pushed in under the bedsteads . The “ badstofa ” is old , the woodwork blackened by age and soot .

It is early spring , a late afternoon . Gudfinna and Oddny are sitting on the beds facing each other , Gudfinna mending shoes , Oddny putting patches on a coat . The Shepherd Boy is standing in the middle of the room , throwing a dart adorned with red cock 's feathers . The costumes are old Icelandic .

sp.speaker: The Boy
sp.p: throws his dartHo ! ho ! I came pretty near hitting her that time !

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: Hitting whom ?

sp.speaker: The Boy
sp.p: Ca n't you see the little spider hanging down from the beam ? I mean to shoot and break her thread .

sp.speaker: Oddny
sp.p: You are always up to some tomfoolery .

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: Leave the poor creature in peace ! It has done you no harm .

sp.speaker: The Boy
sp.p: laughingDo you think she 'd break her legs if she should happen to fall down on the floor ?

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: I wo n't have it ! Destroying a spider 's web is sure to bring bad luck , and you 'll end by tearing the window-pane with your dart .

sp.speaker: The Boy
sp.p: Kari has told me of a man who broke a bow-string with one shot , and that from way off .Shoots .

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: If you do n't stop , you shall wear your shoes with the holes in them .

sp.speaker: The Boy
sp.p: pulling the dart out of the beamWould you rather have me shoot your ear-locks ?

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: Are you crazy , lad ? You might hit my eyes .

sp.speaker: The Boy
sp.p: I must have some kind of fun . I think I 'll have a shot at Oddny 's plaits .

sp.speaker: Oddny
sp.p: If you dare !

sp.speaker: The Boy
sp.p: laughingIf I have bad luck , you will look at Kari with only one eye .

sp.speaker: Oddny
sp.p: You need a good spanking .

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: Kari ought not to have given you that dart .

sp.speaker: The Boy
sp.p: going to the spider , makes a fanning motion with his handUp , old spinning-woman , if you bode good ! Down , if you bode ill ! Up , if you bode good ! Down , if you bode ill !

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: You are awfully hard on your shoes , worse than a grown man . I hope you do n't walk on the sharpest stones just for fun ?

sp.speaker: Oddny
sp.p: Of course he does !

sp.speaker: The Boy
sp.p: The sheep were so restless to-day . Some of them came near slipping away from me .

sp.speaker: Oddny
sp.p: If they had , you would n't be riding such a high horse now !

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: Have they been bad to you , laddie ? Do you never feel timid when you are alone so much ?

sp.speaker: The Boy
sp.p: Sometimes I keep thinking what I should do if a mad bull came tearing down the mountains .

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: Do n't speak of them ! They are the worst monsters in the world — except , perhaps , the skoffin .

sp.speaker: The Boy
sp.p: What is a skoffin ?

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: Do n't you know that ? When a rooster gets to be very old , he lays an egg , and if that 's hatched , it becomes a skoffin . It kills a man by just looking at him , and the only thing that can slay it is a church-blessed silver bullet . Indeed , there are many things you have to be careful of , my child . Are you not afraid of the outlaws ? They 're not good , those fellows ; they go about in skins with the wool on them and carry long sticks with ice-spurs , and that at midsummer . Have you ever seen anything of them ?

sp.speaker: The Boy
sp.p: No , but yesterday I pretty near got scared . There came a man with a big bag under his arm . I did n't know him at first , but it was only Arnes .

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: And what did he want of you ?

sp.speaker: The Boy
sp.p: He asked me to show him the way to a spring . He was thirsty .

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: You had better not have too much talk with him .Hands him the shoes .There ! Now they will last till to-morrow anyway .Kneels down , pulls out a box , and examines its contents .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: It is time for the sheep to be milked .

sp.speaker: The Boy
sp.p: I am going now to drive them home . I was waiting for my shoes .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Have you seen anything of the cows to-day ?

sp.speaker: The Boy
sp.p: No .To Oddny .When I get rich I 'll give you a cow 's tail to tie up your plaits with .

sp.speaker: Oddny
sp.p: Hold your tongue !

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: smilingI heard him teasing you a while ago .

sp.speaker: Oddny
sp.p: He 's forever pestering me about Kari — as if I cared !

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: with a little laughExit .Well , Sigrid does n't take such good care of Magnus 's clothes as you of Kari 's .

sp.speaker: Oddny
sp.p: is silent for a moment and looks at the doorIf I were a widow and owned a farm , the men would be noticing me too , even if I had been nothing but a poor orphan servant girl before I married — like some others .

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: rising , a pair of stockings in her handWhat are you talking about ?Pushes the box under the bed .

sp.speaker: Oddny
sp.p: Do you know who was Halla 's father ?

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: That is what no one seems to know . Some would have it that he was a parson .She darns the stockings .

sp.speaker: Oddny
sp.p: Yes , or a vagabond . There were also some ugly whispers about a stain on her birth .

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: You 'd better bridle your tongue !

sp.speaker: Oddny
sp.p: I am not so dull as you imagine . When Halla thinks no one is looking , she does n't take her eyes from Kari . And she has made him overseer ; that seems queer to others besides me . Last Sunday at church some one asked me if there was anything between the widow and the “ overseer . ”

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: And what did you say ?

sp.speaker: Oddny
sp.p: I told them that it was quite possible Halla had her lines out for him , but that I did not think Kari would swallow the fly , even if it had gold on its wings .

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: Much good it did you , the gospel you heard in church ! I am sorry for you , poor girl ! You are crazy about a man who has neither eye nor ear for you , but that is no reason why you should be running around spreading gossip . Halla is not the kind of woman that is fond of men . There was never a harsh word between her and her husband , God rest his soul , but there was not much love-making between them either . No , indeed !

sp.speaker: Oddny
sp.p: Well , what of that ! He was a man up in years and had a fine farm .

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: He was an upright and honest man , and Halla made him a good wife , my dear .

sp.speaker: Oddny
sp.p: Who doubts that ?Silence .I do n't know what ails Kari of late . Yesterday he flew into a rage when I asked him if he knew of a cure for freckles . I hope Halla has not become such a saint yet that one can n't notice her freckles .

sp.speaker: Kari and Magnus
sp.p: Good evening !

sp.speaker: Gudfinna and Oddny
sp.p: Good evening !

sp.speaker: Oddny
sp.p: risingI am sitting on your bed , I believe .

sp.speaker: Magnus
sp.p: throws off his capOddny , ask Sigrid to come here and pull off my stockings .Sits down .Oddny goes reluctantly .It feels good to sit down .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Why is she so grumpy ? She is not so cheerful a body as you are . I should like to have known you in your young days . I dare say you knew how to handle a rake .

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: straightening her backYou may be sure . On dry ground , two lively fellows had all they could do to make ready for my rake .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: And you were not afraid to tuck up your skirts , where the ground was low and marshy .

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: Indeed not ! Many a time I had water in my shoes .

sp.speaker: Magnus
sp.p: stretching his feet out on the floorPull off my shoes ! I 'm so tired to-night I can n't move .

sp.speaker: Sigrid
sp.p: It must be laziness that ails you , as usual .Kneels down .How in the name of heaven did you manage to get so wet in this dry weather ? I can wring the water out of your stockings .

sp.speaker: Magnus
sp.p: Kari wanted to jump the creek to make a short cut , and I fell in .

sp.speaker: Oddny
sp.p: to KariAre n't you wet , too ?

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: No .Sits down .

sp.speaker: Magnus
sp.p: Kari skims over everything like a bird .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Every man has his gift .To Sigrid .You should see the rocks Magnus can lift .

sp.speaker: Magnus
sp.p: Well , it may be true that I am pretty strong , but I should like to see the man who could throw you in an honest glima .

sp.speaker: Oddny
sp.p: I know one whom Kari could n't stand against .

sp.speaker: Magnus
sp.p: And who is that ?Sigrid pulls at his stockings .There ! There !

sp.speaker: Oddny
sp.p: Bjørn , Halla 's brother-in-law .

sp.speaker: Magnus
sp.p: I should not be afraid to bet on Kari against him .To Sigrid .Give me the stockings !Dries his feet with the stocking legs .

div.stage: Sigrid pulls out a chest , where she finds dry stockings .

sp.speaker: Oddny
sp.p: I do n't think Kari would dare to try a fall with the bailiff .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: If you were the prize , I should not dare to !

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: laughingThere you got it !

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: smilingYet many have fought for less .

sp.speaker: Magnus
sp.p: I 'm ready to make a wager with you , Oddny , that Kari would win .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: It does not look as if the cows were coming home to-night . Magnus , wo n't you go up the gorge and see if they are there , and I will send the boy down to the creek .

div.stage: Exit Sigrid with the wet stockings .

sp.speaker: Magnus
sp.p: Oh , why did I bother to change my stockings !

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: You can take a horse .A dog is heard barking .There ! we shall have company .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: risingI 'll run up there .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: You have your trout nets to look after . I know Magnus wo n't mind .

sp.speaker: Magnus
sp.p: Confound those cows ! Why can n't they come home in time !Puts on his shoes .

div.stage: Kari pulls out a small box from under the bed and begins to whittle teeth for a rake .

sp.speaker: Arnes puts his head in at the door ; he carries a large bag
sp.p: Arnes . Good evening ! I did not want to trouble any one to come to the outside door .Drops his bag on the floor .Now Arnes is rich — there 's gold sand in my bag .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I dare say there is .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: You people do n't know what lies hidden in the hills . I have heard of a man who lost his way in Surt 's Cave . For days he walked underground , and when at last he came up he had gold sand in his shoes .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: What would you do if that were really gold in your bag ?

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: Then Arnes would do many things . You should help yourself to all your hands could hold , and as many times as you have given me shelter , and Arngrim the leper should also fill his fists . I know of no one else to whom I care to do good .

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: And should I have nothing ?

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: I would give you new , long ear-locks of gold .

sp.speaker: Magnus
sp.p: laughingSome little gift you 'd surely have for the bailiff — no ?

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: For him ? Yes , if I could throw the sand into his eyes .Opens the bag and takes out a handful of Iceland moss .They are fine , these lichens , and taste good when you cook them in milk .

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: rising and muttering to herselfExit .The milk !

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: holding up a handfulSee how big they are .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Yes , they are fine .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: patting the bagAnd it is well stuffed , too .

sp.speaker: The Boy
sp.p: Now you can milk the sheep .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: You are not through yet , poor boy . You will have to go down along the creek and look for the cows .

sp.speaker: The Boy
sp.p: Exit .I hope they 're not up to new tricks and begin to stay out nights .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: calling after himTake a drink of milk in the pantry ; the key is in the door .Magnus rises slowly .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: Are you going to buy my bag ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: If you make the price right .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: You ought to have it for nothing — you 've given me shelter and good food so often .Lifts his foot .What I need most just now is to get something on my feet .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I do n't think we shall quarrel about the price .To Magnus .Take it out into the kitchen .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Exit .Will you not sit down ? I 'll go and find you a bite to eat .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: following her with his eyesThat woman has a kind heart .Sits down .How long have you been working here on the farm ?

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: This is my second year .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: And overseer already ? Yes , some folks have luck .Leans toward him .As you may know , I have n't a very good name . I can n't settle down very long at any one place , and it comes hard for me to be anybody 's servant . You must surely have heard me spoken of as a thief ?

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: People will say so many things .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: passing his hand over his earsMy ears are not marked yet , but somehow it sticks to you like dust — what people say — no matter whether it is true or not . Have you ever been the target for gossipy tales ?

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: slowlyNot that I know of .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: Then you have it coming to you . Shall I tell you what they are saying about you in these parts ?

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Is it about me and Halla ?

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: I have heard that too , but this story is about yourself .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: I would rather be spared listening to gossip .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: If I had been quite sure that it was nothing but gossip , I should not have opened my mouth about it .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: laughing coldlyYou are at least frank .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: risingIt is all the same to me , but if you have anything to hide , you had better keep your eyes and ears open , for you have an enemy , that much I can tell you .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: I do n't know that I have harmed any one around here .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: You live and fill your place . That is enough to make enemies .

div.stage: Enter Halla with a wooden mug filled with porridge and milk . The lid is turned back and some meat , dried fish , and butter are placed upon it .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: You get nothing but skimmed milk . I thought you would rather have that than wait until the cows had been milked .Lets down the table-leaf .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: sits down and reaches for the mugGod bless you , woman ! I am used to having it on my knees .Pulls out his pocket-knife and eats .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: stops in front of Kari and looks at himYou are working hard ; there are drops of sweat on your forehead .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Are there ?Wipes his forehead ; looks up .Should you like to know your life beforehand ?Stands up and raises both arms to the ceiling .I have lived where I could touch the roof over my head with my clenched fists , and I have lived where my eyes could not reach it .Sits down .Can you remember how few clothes I had when I came here ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: sitting downI can well remember the green knitted jerkin you wore — you have it yet — and your coat and brown breeches .Smiling .There was a big black patch on the left knee .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: The rags on my back were all I had in the world , and now I own two new sets and even more underclothes . You deserve that I should put teeth of gold in your rake .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: smilingThat rake would be too heavy for me .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: looking at HallaSo many things come back to me to-night that I have not thought of before . You gave me leave to work in the smithy in my spare time instead of doing the wool-carding . You saw to it that I should be one of the men who gather the sheep down from the hills in the fall , because you knew I liked it .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: That was only natural , since you are so swift of foot .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: And for my bed you knitted a coverlet with seven colors in it . You have always been good to me .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Now you are getting far too grateful .To Arnes .Do you think you have enough food there , Arnes ? I can get you some more , if you want it .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: patting his stomachI do n't even know if I can make room for the porridge .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: looking at HallaIf I were to leave this place , I should miss you more than any other living being I have ever known .Rises , pushes the box under the bed .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I hope you will stay here for many years yet .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Exit .Nobody knows what the morrow may bring .

div.stage: Halla follows Kari with her eyes . Silence .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: puts the wooden mug on the tableNow I give thanks for the meal . Will you let me lie in one of your barns to-night ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: You would surely sleep better in a bed . You can lie with Magnus .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: I never sleep better than in old dry hay .

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: Is it true , Arnes , that you can tell what the birds are talking about ?

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: Do they say that ?

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: In olden times there were wise folks who understood all such things , but people nowadays are backward in that as in so many other ways .Sits down .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: smilingYes , young people are not good for much , in your opinion .

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: We need only think of the sagas . Where have we men now like Skarphjedinn and Grettir Asmundsson ? There are none such in these days .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: When I was a child there was nothing I wished so much as that I might have lived with Grettir in his banishment .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: Was it not eighteen years he was an outlaw ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Nineteen . He lived longer as an outlaw than any one else has done . He lacked only one year to become free .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: He must have been a great man , but that brings to my mind what the leper said the other day , when the talk turned to the old sagas .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: And what did he say ?

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: Distance makes mountains blue and mortals great .

sp.speaker: The Boy
sp.p: The bailiff is coming on horseback .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: risingWhat can he want so late ? Did you find the cows ?

sp.speaker: The Boy
sp.p: Yes , I met them coming home . They are in .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Did you tell the girls ?

sp.speaker: The Boy
sp.p: Exit .No .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Gudfinna , you go and ask him to come in .Gudfinna rises .You wo n't forget about the milk ?

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: risingNow I think I shall go and seek my bed .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: smilingDo n't you want to have a talk with the bailiff ?

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: If I had found some dead sheep up in the hills with his mark on their ears , I 'd gladly have told him so .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Sleep well !

div.stage: Enter Bjørn , carrying a riding-whip with a silver-mounted handle and a leather lash ; he wears riding-socks reaching above the knees .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Good evening !

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: pointing to his feetI did not take off my socks . I see now that they are not quite clean .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Will you be seated ? May I offer you anything ?

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: No , thank you . I want nothing .Sits down .You know I have not far to come . The sorrel and I can make it in fifteen minutes , when we are in the humor .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: How is everything at your place ? Have you any news ?

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: That depends on what you mean . Who was that I met in the hall ? It was quite dark there .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: It must have been Arnes .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: Is he spending the night here ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: It is no concern of mine , but I doubt if my late brother would have sheltered men of his kind , and yet he had the name of being hospitable .Takes a snuff-box from his pocket .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: sitting downI know nothing wrong of Arnes , and I do know that he is grateful for what I can offer him .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: I thought you had heard the common talk . His record is not of the best , I am sorry to say . I have been told that little things are apt to be missing where he has made his stay .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I would rather bear such a loss in silence than perhaps throw suspicion on an innocent man .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: Finely thought ! Yet some one must be the first to warn the unwary .Takes snuff .You must hear what happened to me not long ago . The boy lost two milch sheep up in the hills . I was vexed that it should occur so early in the summer when they still had their wool , and therefore I sent one of my men to look for them . Near Red Peak he found tracks of the sheep and also the footprints of a large man .Lowering his voice .You could do me a good turn if you would give Arnes a pair of new shoes ; I should pay for them , of course . He will not suspect anything , if you do it . Then you keep his old shoes for me .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: risingNo , I will have nothing to do with that .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: Then we sha n't speak of it any more . I think I shall find out what I am after , nevertheless .He is silent .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: You surely did n't come here to-night for Arnes 's sake ?

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: I did not . Was Kari at church last Sunday ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Why do you ask ?

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: I know that he was there .Sits down .You are satisfied with him as an overseer ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: sits downIn every way .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: All the same , I advise you to get rid of him , the sooner the better .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: laughingI thank you for your kind advice .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: My advice is not to be scorned , and besides , am I not your brother-in-law ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: My sheep had to learn that to their cost , when they strayed in on your pastures , and you set your dogs on them .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: Even though we have not always been as neighborly as I might wish , you must listen to me this time . I have always disliked Kari ; I would never have hired that man . Believe me , there is something underhanded about him . Nobody knows him , and no one has heard of his people . It is as if he had shot up out of the ground . The only thing you know about him is that his name is Kari , and you do n't even know that .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: risingWhat are you driving at with all this ?

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: Sit still .Halla sits down .Last fall two strangers who stopped on their journey through here thought they knew Kari . They said it was easier to change one 's name than one 's face . As bad luck would have it , I did not get a chance to talk with them myself , but my suspicions were roused . Now there is a man staying with me who has just come from the south . He saw Kari at church last Sunday , and if he is right , it is an ugly story .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: risingNeither more nor less than that your overseer 's name is not Kari but Eyvind , that he was locked up for theft , and got away .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: has risenYou must be mad , both of you .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: The man would not swear that he had seen right .Smiles .Somehow he seemed sorry that he had told me . He said he had never seen two people more alike , and Eyvind had a scar on his forehead just as Kari has — that much he remembered plainly .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: It was last Sunday at church that he saw Kari ?

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: laughingKari was not at church last Sunday .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: That 's queer . Two of my men were there . But we can easily solve that riddle , if I bring my guest over here to-morrow .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I do n't believe for a moment that Kari is a thief .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: You need not believe it . Simply tell him what I have said , and that I mean to have the judge look into the matter . I warrant he will be out of the house before sunrise .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: You are quick to believe evil and quick to run to the judge , but in this case you will not reap much honor .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: If you suppose I shall act hastily , you are mistaken . I shall write to the county that Eyvind hails from and give the letter to my guest , who will see that it gets safely and speedily into the proper hands . The answer can be here within two or three months .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Is it out of kindness to me that you are so eager about this matter ?

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: If it is true what people say , it would be best for you that Kari should take himself away from here as fast as can be . You might find it harder to part from him two or three months hence .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: icilyNow you show your real self . You did not come here to give me kind counsel , nor do I look for such from you , but you had better leave me and my household in peace . Do you think I have forgotten what you did to me ? When your brother told you that he intended to marry me , you thought it would be a disgrace to the family for him to make a poor servant girl his wife . You urged him to satisfy his fleeting passion , as you called it , without any marriage .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: I never said that .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: laying her hand on her heartIn here I have a sealed book in which I keep the words my friends have spoken . And I have more to tell you . There was something behind it — your fear of losing a part of your power .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: What are you saying ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Did that prick your soul , you godly man ! You knew that your brother would follow your advice like a child , but you had misgivings that you could not work me like dough in your hands , and what you feared came true . You can never forget that I made my husband stand on his own feet . I know your greed for power ! But now I warn you for all time to let me and mine alone .Sits down .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: flushed with anger , but still controlling his voiceMuch have I learned to-night that I did not know before . Now I see why you made Kari overseer . You are not your mother 's daughter for nothing .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: her lips tremblingYou want to make me angry . You can n't do it . Nor shall you succeed in blackening Kari in my eyes . You were hoping that I should hurt him by telling him what you have said . I shall not tell him .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: You will talk differently when I hold the proof in my hand .Shakes his hand ; goes toward the door .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: rising , hatred burning in her eyesJust before you came , the servants were making bets about who was best at glima , you or Kari . Oddny was the only one who stood up for you . Kari thought you had grown so old and stiff in your joints that you would not dare to go in for a wrestling-match .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: Tell Kari that I am ready to meet him this evening , if he wishes it .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: No , I shall tell Kari that you have given your word to wrestle with him at the big sheep-folds in the fall . I hope to have a good many witnesses , when the bailiff bites the dust .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: Exit .I will fight him whenever and wherever he may wish — anywhere but in jail . Good-bye ! Hallastands motionless for a moment ; passes her hands down over her face ; goes to the door ; callsGudfinna ! Gudfinna !Goes back into the room ; again passes her hands down over her face .

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: Has the bailiff gone ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: He came near upsetting me in the hall and did n't even say good evening .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Do sweep the floor ! I wo n't have in here the dirt he has dragged with him .

div.stage: Gudfinna takes a bird 's wing and sweeps .

sp.speaker: The Boy
sp.p: shoutingCome and see what we have caught !

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: Not so noisy ! Did you catch a whale ?

sp.speaker: The Boy
sp.p: We got a salmon — so big !Shows the size with his hands .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Tell Kari to come here ; I want to speak with him . I will let you take care of the salmon . Open and clean it , sprinkle some salt on it , and lay it in fresh grass overnight .

sp.speaker: The Boy
sp.p: Wo n't you look at it before it is cut ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: patting his cheekYou big baby ! Do you think I have never seen a salmon before ? Now run and tell Kari that I want to speak to him .

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: calling after him through the doorAnd tell him to lift the milk pot from the fire .

lg.l: If the coals are good , I must ask you to do some baking to-night for

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: Exit .The coals are good enough .

div.stage: Halla stands listening . Footsteps are heard in the hall .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: You wanted to speak to me ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I hear you have made a fine catch . Thank you ! I have promised the bailiff that you shall meet him in a glima at the folds in the autumn . What do you say to that ?

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: I call that great news , but surely that was not what he came here for to-night ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: No , he had another errand . He spoke ill of you .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: What did he say ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: There is a man just come from the south who saw you at church last Sunday . He told Bjørn that you looked like some one by the name of Eyvind , a thief who had run away . He even thought he recognized the scar on your forehead .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: in a low voice , sitting downAnd did the bailiff believe the man was right ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: He said I should tell you that he meant to speak to the judge , and that then you would flee from here this very night .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: rising with a loud laughThis is to laugh at . Do you know when they will come to catch the thief !

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: has been looking at him steadily ; holds out her hand to himGive me your hand , Kari , and say that you have nothing to fear from any man .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: evasivelyI understand that this seems strange to you , but the man who saw me must be some one who has a grudge against me from former days , and does this out of spite .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: What do I care about him or about the bailiff ! Say that you are innocent !

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: So you doubt me , too !

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: aloofI have no right to call you to task .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: warmlyI know of no one in the world whom I would rather trust than you .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: You are innocent ?

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Yes , in this I am innocent .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: God be praised !Puts her hand on her heart .If it had been otherwise , I do n't see how I could have borne it .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: I shall remember the bailiff for this .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: in an outburst of joyLet him do his worst ! What care we ! I am so happy now that I know you are innocent , I could kiss you for joy .Exultantly .Kari , will you be my husband ?

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: terrifiedNo , Halla , I cannot . Hallastares at him , speechless . Suddenly she goes close to him and scans his faceHave you a wife ?

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I could not believe that your eyes lied this evening .Stamps her foot with anger and shame .Take yourself away from here ! Go !Covers her face with her hands ; rocks to and fro .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: My eyes did not lie to-night .Stands for a moment in terrible emotion ; then begins to walk up and down .I knew a man named Eyvind . His father was poor and had many children . Eyvind was the next to the oldest . It was said in those parts that thieving ran in the blood of his kin , though no one could say anything against Eyvind 's father .Halla looks up , listening .Two years ago or more , toward the end of the winter , it happened , as often before , that there was no food in the house . Eyvind went to the parson to ask him to help them out with food . He offered to pay for it with his work in the spring , but the parson refused . It was late in the evening , dark and snowing . The road to Eyvind 's home went past the parson 's sheep-cots .As Kari proceeds , he now and then passes his hand over his forehead .They loomed before him like a big black mound . Then the temptation came over him . The herdsman had gone home , the snow would cover up the tracks , and the parson was rich enough . I hated him !Halla rises .Late that night , Eyvind came home with a fine big sheep . The next day , word came from the parson . They had found his mittens in the sheep-cot . Eyvind was locked up and given ten years in prison . They thought they could prove that he had more thefts to answer for —He breaks off suddenly .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: breathlesslyKari !

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: My name is not Kari — it is Eyvind . I was sentenced for theft . I fled and lived one year in the hills as an outlaw .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: After this I shall never believe in any one .Sits down and bursts into tears .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: kneelingDo with me what you will . Drive me out of your house — now — this evening , or give me into the hands of the law , but you must forgive me . It was our poverty and the snow that made me steal .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: risingI will not cry . It is stupid to cry . Get up ! I am no God that you should ask my forgiveness .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: rising to his feetIt is lonesome to live a whole winter up there in the hills . That is why I ventured down here , far from home , and under a new name . Since then I have gone about like one who walks in his sleep , afraid of the awakening . Many a time have I made up my mind to tell you the whole truth , but somehow it seemed to get harder with every day that passed . I have never understood why it was so before to-night , but now I know it , and now I can speak of it . Kari has loved you . You are the only woman he has ever loved , but now Kari is no more , and never has been anything but the dream of a poor and unhappy man .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Say no more !

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: He has loved you long , but never until to-night has he seen how beautiful you are .Carried away .Like a blue mountain rising from the mist !

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: stepping close to himClose your eyes , Kari , and sleep yet a while . Kiss me !

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: kissing herI will sleep with my eyes open .

div.head: ACT II

stage.stage: A resting-place near one of the large folds into which the sheep are driven in the autumn , when they are gathered down from the hills . A grass-grown dell . On the left , a steep heather-covered slope , here and there in the heather gray , jutting stones . To the right , a low bluff , where grass , flowers , and juniper bushes grow in the clefts and on the ledges . Toward the background , the bluff becomes lower and more bushy , and bending somewhat to the left , it partly shuts off the view into a hilly , rock-studded landscape with the distant mountains beyond . In the foreground , at the foot of the bluff , several saddles . The women 's saddles have broad , brass-mounted backs .

sp.speaker: It is a fine autumn day . Gudfinna alone is busy with the luggage
sp.p: Enter Arngrim carrying a roll of paper under his arm . His face is livid and drawn .

sp.speaker: Arngrim
sp.p: So you are all alone here .

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: Indeed I am . I did not want to leave the luggage , and it seemed a pity to keep the boy from the folds .

sp.speaker: Arngrim
sp.p: Is Halla up at the folds ?

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: I do n't know where she is now . She is so restless to-day . A while ago she climbed up on a knoll to see if the last drove was coming down from the hills . I hardly know whether it 's the sheep or Kari she is looking for .

sp.speaker: Arngrim
sp.p: We do n't get tired of watching for what we are looking forward to . I have but one thing to look forward to .Sits down on one of the rocks .

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: And what is that , poor fellow ?

sp.speaker: Arngrim
sp.p: To hear the nails being driven into my coffin . Then I should say like the man in the story : “ Now I 'd laugh if I were n't dead . ”

div.stage: Enter Halla , happy and smiling , wearing a silver girdle around her waist .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: The last flock is coming , and it is not the smallest . Kari is with it .

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: Of course he is with it .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: laughingYes , of course .To Arngrim .I am glad to see you here .

sp.speaker: Arngrim
sp.p: Did you happen to bring anything good from home ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: smilingYou never can tell .Searching in one of the saddle-bags , she finds a blue flask which she hands to Arngrim .You may keep the bottle .

sp.speaker: Arngrim
sp.p: That is just like you .Holds the flask up to the light .There are juniper berries in it .Takes a pull .It is like drinking sunshine .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: has moved toward the background and stands gazingWhat a change in the sheep since spring . Then they were yellow and dirty , but now they are white as ptarmigans in winter . It always makes me happy to see a flock of sheep coming down the mountain side .

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: Kari 's shoes must be a sight . He does n't save his legs , that man .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: No , you are right in that .Goes to Gudfinna .But he runs swifter than any one else .

sp.speaker: Arngrim
sp.p: No one can run away from his fate , were he fleeter than the wind .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: turns to ArngrimAre you sure of that ? May not a strong will turn the tide of fate ?

sp.speaker: Arngrim
sp.p: My fate no one can alter .Looks up .An old song comes to my mind when I look at you . I cannot remember how it runs , but it is about some one who had the thoughts of her soul written on her forehead .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: smilingExit .I feel only the sun shining on my brow .

sp.speaker: Arngrim
sp.p: She deserves to be happy .Brings out the roll of paper .Should you like to see what I am doing to make the days slip by ?

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: goes to himYes , let me look at it . Arngrimopens the roll , which is seen to contain drawings in bright colorsThese are birds from the garden of Eden — too bad I never heard them sing !— and here is a blue flower so sensitive that it closes at the slightest touch , and here is a small plant from Gethsemane with red berries lying like drops of blood on the ground .

sp.speaker: The Boy
sp.p: Kari is coming !

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: We know that .

sp.speaker: The Boy
sp.p: I must be off again to help drive the sheep into the fold .Leaps with joy .Exit .What fun to be here ! It 's most as good as Christmas !

sp.speaker: Arngrim
sp.p: He skips about like a merry little lamb .

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: calling after himTake care the rams do n't butt you !

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Now the sheep will soon be at the fold .Brushes her hair back from her forehead .Are n't you clever enough to know a cure for freckles ? I am so tired of my freckles .

sp.speaker: Arngrim
sp.p: smilingPerhaps you have a new looking-glass .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: smilingPerhaps I have .

div.stage: Enter Jon and two other peasants , followed directly by two peasant women , Jon 's Wife , and her friend with two little daughters , eight and nine years old .

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: slightly intoxicatedNow a bite of shark 's meat would taste first-rate . You did n't happen to be so thoughtful as to bring some , did you ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: laughingThat is just what I did .Looks in the saddle-bags .

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: Did n't I tell you so !Takes a brandy-flask out of his pocket .Do you mind if I bring out my bottle ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Please yourself . Jonsits down . The others follow suit , until only the children remain standingIf I did n't have so fine a wife , I should have asked you to marry me long ago .Takes a pull at the flask and hands it to the one sitting next to him .Let the bottle go the rounds ! Hallato Jon 's WifeYour husband is happy to-day . Jon 's Wife . Yes , he loves everybody to-day .

sp.speaker: First Peasant
sp.p: hands the flask to JonThanks !

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: Do n't think I am forgetting you , Arngrim .Hands him the flask .

sp.speaker: Arngrim
sp.p: The blood grows colder as one gets old , and then the warmth of the bottle feels good . Hallahands Jon a piece of shark 's meatHelp yourself .

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: Bless you ! My mouth waters .Takes a knife from his pocket and cuts off a slice .It is white as milk and sweet-smelling . I say , shark 's meat and brandy are the best things the Lord ever made — next to women !Hands the fish to one of the peasants .Hallafinds a piece of sugar-candy and divides it between the childrenHave the little girls been to the folds before ?

sp.speaker: Peasant Woman
sp.p: No , this is the first time . I promised them last spring that if they were good and worked hard I would bring them , and they have surely earned it . It 's past belief how much they can do , no older than they are .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Did you see the last flock ? That was a large one .Goes toward the background .Jon 's Wife . Indeed it was .

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: My brown bell-wether was the leader of the flock . He generally stays in the hills till they gather in the sheep for the last time , unless there are signs of bad weather .Gudfinna crosses over to the peasant women and fingers their clothes . They stand talking together .

sp.speaker: First Peasant
sp.p: I should not wonder if the winter were to come early after so good a summer .

sp.speaker: Second Peasant
sp.p: God knows how many sheep the hills have taken this year ! Do you remember those cold days in the spring ? It may be a good many lambs froze to death .

sp.speaker: First Peasant
sp.p: And then those cursed foxes !

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: The foxes are nothing to the men — both those down here and those in the hills .

sp.speaker: Second Peasant
sp.p: I do n't believe there is anybody living in the hills , at least not in these parts .

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: You do n't believe it ? I tell you , my good man , there are more outlaws than you think . To my mind , the laws are to blame for it . If I had my say , all thieves would be strung up .

sp.speaker: Second Peasant
sp.p: Well , I look at it in another way . I believe the laws are too strict . It seems to me it is making too much of the sheep , when a man is locked up for life because he has stolen two or three of them .

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: You always have to be of a different mind from anybody else .

sp.speaker: Second Peasant
sp.p: I do n't know about that , but those who flee to the hills do it from need . If the laws were milder , I believe there would be no outlaws . What do you say , Arngrim ?

sp.speaker: Arngrim
sp.p: If we were all to be judged by our thoughts , the hills would be swarming with outlaws .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: It is too light yet to be talking about thieves . Ca n't you tell us something funny ? Jon 's Wife . Tell about our calf .

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: laughingWhen he saw the sun for the first time in his life , he fell down on his tail from fright .

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: There comes the man who can tell us stories .Rises and goes to meet him .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: Good day to you all ! So you want a story ?

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: You shall have a drink if you tell us a story , but it must be a good one .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: Hand me the bottle .Drinks .I could tell you some spook stories that would make your hair stand on end , but they are better told in the gloaming .Laughs .The girls are less afraid of us men folks when they hear about spooks .

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: laughingYes , of two evils men are better than spooks .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: sees HallaNow I know what I shall tell you . Hush ! Once upon a time there were two outlaws . What their crime had been I do n't know , but they had to flee to the hills to save their lives . They found a green spot among the glaciers , hemmed in by huge rocks . There they built their hut , for there they knew they would be left in peace . But the hills were hankering for their old loneliness and hated those two , and swore they would drive them away . First they sent the storms and the frost . There came a winter night so terrible that the roots of the grass trembled with fear under the snow , but unknown to those two their love had built an invisible wall around the hut , and the storm and the snow could not get in . Then the hills sent hunger . It came to them in their dreams , tempting them with sweet-smelling hot bread and butter fresh from the churn . It would have them barter their love —

sp.speaker: The Farm Hand
sp.p: Is Arnes here by any chance ?

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: Here I am .

sp.speaker: The Farm Hand
sp.p: There is a sheep with earmarks that nobody can make out . Will you come over and take a look at it ?

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: risingNo peace to be had !

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: holding out her hand to ArnesArnes takes Halla 's hand . Exit .Thanks for the story .

sp.speaker: The Farm Hand
sp.p: to JonYour brown bell-wether ran away from the men as they were trying to drive it in .

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: risingThat promises a fine fall .All the peasants rise .Jon 's Wifeto HallaWe shall see each other later .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Exeunt peasants .So we shall .

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: They have not been sparing of the shark 's meat .Packs it away .

div.stage: Enter Kari , warm from running , happy and smiling .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Good day to you , Halla !Shakes hands with her .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: has gone to meet KariGood day to you , and welcome back !

sp.speaker: Arngrim
sp.p: risingExit .Now I am so drunk that I can enjoy listening to the bleating of the sheep . By the way , washing with lukewarm milk is good for freckles .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Thanks !To Gudfinna .You may go now , if you like . You have been here with the luggage long enough .

div.stage: Halla and Kari stand silent until Gudfinna has disappeared . Then Kari draws her to him and kisses her .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I would rather wait for you here than meet you at the fold . I was so frightened ! I thought you had gone and would never come back .Takes his hand and looks at him in loving wonder .Where do you get your courage ? I can n't understand that you have not fled long ago .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: I will tell you where I get my courage .Kisses her .I do n't know how the days can be so gloriously long . It seems to me that I have lived more than the age of man since the first time you kissed me .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: You love me !

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: is silent for a momentI love you .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: You do n't know how much that one word promises me . It means the sunshine on the hills . It means the streams and lakes . Shall I tell you something , Kari ? Something you do n't know ?

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: What could that be ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I am not going to say it just now , but I will tell you something else . I care a thousand times more for you now than I did three months ago . Do you know why ?

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Because you are so brave . You sleep in my arms as calmly as if you had not a foe in the whole country .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: smilingI must have borrowed your courage .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: It is dear to see you smile . Your hair is like a cloud , and when you smile it seems to lift from your forehead .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: You must not make me out braver than I am . Part of my courage is recklessness . I close my eyes and let the sun shine on my face .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Do you never think of the future ?

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: earnestlyI do .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I have blamed myself much these last days . I ought to have sent you away long ago , but I could not . I had to be sure that you loved me . Last night I heard the hills calling you , and I called against them with all my soul . If you had never come back , I would have forgiven you , though it had broken my heart .Exultantly .And then I saw you coming down the mountain like a god , driving a white snowslide before you !

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Did you think I could have gone without letting you know ? I remember once you had fallen asleep in my arms . The night was light . Your eyes were closed , but I could see through your eyelids . I saw a little girl with black hair .Fondly stroking her hair .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: taking his right handHow well I know this hand !Lays it on her heart .My heart beats with joy .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: I am like the man in the fairy-tale who fell down into a deep well . He thought he would never again see the sun , but suddenly he stood in a green meadow . There was a tall castle , and the king 's daughter came out to meet him . Halla , do you understand ? If I had not stolen , we two should never have met .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: That is true .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: The year I lived in the hills , I would sometimes get into such a rage that I wanted to give myself a good thrashing . Once I really did it — I beat myself with a knotted rope .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: How you must have suffered !

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: If anybody had told me in those days that I should ever become a happy man , I would have laughed at him . Then I believed riches and honors meant happiness . I used to dream of riding through the parish where I was born , dressed in fine clothes and with many horses .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: laughingI did not know you were vain .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Nor am I any more , but I have grown stingy . The minutes are my gold-pieces .Takes her hand .When I hold your hand in mine , I am happy . Before I cared for you , I did not see the sun shining , and now when it rains , all the drops prattle about you .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: You do love me !

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: I seem to be in a church . I hold a torch in my hand and light one taper after another . For every taper that is lighted , the church grows larger and more beautiful . But I am a thief . If I am caught I must be buried alive , and now the church-bells are ringing . I hear the crowd gathering outside .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: You frighten me .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: taking her face between his handsI must have a long look at your face . If I were to become blind this moment , I should always remember it . Your soul is in your eyes . When you look at me , I feel an unseen hand fondling my face . Whenever the sun shines , I shall see your eyes . It is hard to tell you , but when the sky grows red to-morrow , I shall be on my way to the hills . I must flee this very night .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I knew it .Sits down .Tell me how you have planned your flight .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: I must be off before the winter sets in , and besides the letter from the south may be here any day now .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I know all that .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: sits downWhen I come home to-night , I shall say that I have seen the tracks of a flock of sheep farther up in the hills than we usually go to look for them . I shall ask you for two horses . You wo n't refuse me them ?Halla shakes her head .I shall say that I must start at once , this very night , before the tracks disappear . When I do n't come back , they will think I have come across outlaws or have met with an accident .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: And where shall you go ?

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: To the mountain plain where the warm springs are . I lived there before I came to you .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: How long will it take you to reach it ?

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Three days . It is about in the middle of the country .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: And there you will build your hut ?

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: No ; last time I lived in a lava cave . I had brought with me some tools that my brother gave me , and I left them there . Something told me that I might need them again .He is silent .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: taking his handYou must tell me more , much more . I want to see the place where you will livewith a strange smile, so that I can come and visit you in my thoughts .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: I forget what I have told you and what I have not told you . You may think that the hills are wild and forbidding , but that is not so at all . In the summer , when the sun is shining , they are beautiful . The glaciers lie like white untrodden land in a sea of sand , their lower rim flashing green and blue in the sunlight . When you come nearer , you see a chain of jagged sandhills like a dark surf , where the glacier and the sand waste meet .He is silent again . Halla has picked a flower and is pulling its petals .Why are you doing that ? What are you asking about ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: You love me !

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Do you need to ask a flower about that ?Rising .Are you not the least bit sorry that we must part ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: risingWould it make it easier for you , if I were to whine and weep like a child ?

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: I do n't know .He is silent .Yet you need not pity me . I am rich — I am king of the hills ! The fire on my hearth never dies , day or night . The country is mine , as far as my eyes can reach . Mine are the glaciers that make the streams ! When I get angry , they swell , and the stones gnash their teeth against the current . And I own a whole lake with a fleet of ice-ships and a choir of swans .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I never said that I pitied you .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: But one thing you must promise me . You must not marry the bailiff .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: But , dear man —

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: If you do , I shall come some night and kill you both , first him and then you .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Are you really jealous of the bailiff ? He hates me .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Why should he be hounding me like a wild beast , if it were not for your sake ? I have never done him any harm .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I promise you that I shall never marry the bailiff .Puts her arms around his neck and tries to draw him to her .Kiss me , Kari !

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: gently pushing her awayMy name is not Kari . From this day on my name is Eyvind — “ Eyvind of the Hills , ” they call me in the southland , my brother told me .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: From my lips you shall never hear any other name than Kari . By that name I learned to love you . A man who is not loved has no name .Takes his hands .Kariin a sudden outburst , drawing her to him and kissing her foreheadGod bless you , Halla !With difficulty mastering his voice .Now I am going to the fold .Turns away from Halla .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: callingKari !Kari turns back .Must I ask you to marry me a second time ? I thought we two were married .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: So we are before God .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: So far as I know , it is the custom that when a man moves from one place to another , he takes his wife with him .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Do you think there is anything in the world I would rather do than live with you ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Then ask me if I am willing .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Will you be my beloved wife and go with me through all suffering ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I will !

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Will you take upon yourself half of my guilt and become an outcast like me ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: exultantlyI will !

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Will you face hunger and cold and all terrors for my sake ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Have you not always known that I would go with you ? Could you believe me so low that I would keep you here with this dread hanging over you , if I had not meant to go with you ? Every night I thought : To-morrow he will ask if you will go with him .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: How beautiful you are ! All the days we have had together live in your face !

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Did you believe I could rest satisfied in thinking of you with the mountains between us ? Then you do n't know me yet . I will live ! I will sail with you in your white ships !

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: Good day to you , Halla . I looked for you at the fold . It is a long time since we two neighbors have met .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: confusedYes , it is a long time .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: Who sees to it that your sheep are taken out of the fold ? Your cots seem to be standing empty .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Kari attends to that .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: Then it is time you sent him about his work .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Perhaps the bailiff has come to lend a hand ?

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: to HallaI should like to have a few words with you .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: We were just starting for the fold . Perhaps we could have our talk on the way up .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: If it is the same to you , I prefer to stay here . It is a matter of some weight , which I do not care to discuss in the presence of your overseer or any one but yourself .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: to KariThen you had better go up to the fold .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Exit .Do n't forget to ask the bailiff if it is true that he has been rubbing his knee-joints with fat every night the whole summer through .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: He 's bold enough , that fellow . It is well we shall soon be rid of him .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: rousedAnd what was it you wanted to see me about ?

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: We were both somewhat angry when we met last . Shall we let it be forgotten ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: relievedI thought perhaps you had got your letter from the southland with the proofs that you had been wrong in your suspicions .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: Everything in good time . Did you say anything to him ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I told you I would n't .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: I might have known that , since he is still here . Do you think I am beginning to look old ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: amazedTo me you look as you have always looked .Watches him keenly .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: I admit you were right in some of the things you said to me when we met last , but we all have our failings , and since my mother died I have had no one who dared to speak plainly to me except you .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: You may not often have wished to listen to others .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: Perhaps you are right , but somehow there must be two different souls in every one of us .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Have you had a good hay crop this summer ?

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: Fairly good . At least I have enough for myself . Do n't you understand what I want to say to you , or do n't you want to understand ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: You said that it was a matter of weight . That is all I know .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: I am not skilled in fine words . Could you think of becoming my wife ?Halla laughs . Bjørn flushes .Is that so laughable ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: You can n't be in earnest .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: In dead earnest . I shall soon be forty-eight years old , but you are not a child any longer either , and we are of equal standing . If we two marry and make our farms into one , I think we should have to look outside of this parish for a finer property .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: So we two should marry in order to join our farms ?

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: I will not deny that I should like to see the boundary line gone between the two farms , but that is not the reason why I have made up my mind to ask you to marry me . It is not good for a man to be alone , and you are the only woman in this parish whom I could think of taking for a wife . You are healthy and strong of body , and you are good-looking . What answer do you give ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I must have some time to think it over . This comes upon me unawares . Within three days you shall have my answer . Are you satisfied with that ?

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: I think it is but natural that you should want some time to make up your mind , and all the more as we have not always been the best of friends . Perhaps you will now more readily understand why I did not wish you to have a thief as overseer of your farm , and I am sorry to say that my distrust was well founded .Pulls from his pocket a letter with a large seal .This letter came yesterday .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: holding out her handMay I see it ?

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: It is an official letter , which I do not like to give out of my hands , but I am not afraid to trust you with it .Halla takes the letter ; reads .I can lend you one of my men to drive your sheep home this evening , for you will have to do without your overseer . It is lucky that the judge is here to-day .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I shall keep this letter .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: I can understand a joke .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Kari has been with me for more than a year . He has been a hard worker and an able man . I will not have any one lay hands on him so long as he is in my service . I want to give him a chance to get away . That is what you yourself advised , three months ago .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: At that time the case was very different . There was no proof of his guilt then .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: putting her hand to her foreheadI can n't believe yet that he is a thief .Hands the letter to Bjørn .Bjørn , I beg of you to show me a great favor . You must let this matter rest , till we get home .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: In that I cannot serve you .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Perhaps I can do something for you in return .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: I do n't understand how you can pity a felon and a thief .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Nor do I understand it myself , but somehow I do . You have just asked me if I would be your wife . Surely you will grant me the first thing I ask of you !

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: One would think you were pleading for your best friend .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I may have cared more for him than I knew myself . If you will let him get away , I shall have no objection to making our two farms into one .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: I never thought your overseer would be the means of my getting you for a wife , but I yield on those terms . Once we are married , you will surely forget him . But he must be gone from here within twenty-four hours , and I want you to know that if he ever shows himself in these parts again , he will have to take his punishment .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: You need have no fear that he will ever come back here .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: Then let us forget all about him . You have saved him from jail for a time , but he 's sure to end there any way .Goes to her .Who would have thought that you should become my little wife !Tries to put his arm around her waist .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: draws backSo many things happen that we do not look for .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: You are just in time . It will surely please you to hear that your mistress is to marry me within a short time .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: turning to HallaWhat does this mean ?

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: laughingYou had n't expected this .Goes to Halla .My sweetheart might give me a kiss .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: warding him offNo , no ! Karigrasping Bjørn 's armThat man lies ! She is mine .To Halla .If you two get married to-morrow , still you are mine .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: Exit .Has my brother 's wife become a harlot ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: What have you done , Kari ? It was to save you I promised to be his wife . I hoped to get a chance to speak to you . He has the letter and is going to give you up to the judge to-day .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: I could not bear that man to touch you .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: You must run for the horses and flee !

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: That would be madness . The others have just as good horses . We must take what comes . I shall deny everything .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: What good would that do ? It is impossible to mistake the description . I have read it myself .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Did you really mean to marry the bailiff to save my life ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I lied to him , so that I could flee with you . I hate him .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: I love you , Halla .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: in rising fearWhat shall we do ?Wrings her hands .It is all my fault for holding you back .On the point of weeping .I am an unhappy woman .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: You must not cry . Even if I faced the death warrant , I should not be sorry that I stayed .Kisses her hands .These summer days we have had together — in all eternity no one can take them from us .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: withdraws her hands excitedlyDo n't you know of any way ? Say that the bailiff is your enemy and has had the letter framed up .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: You know yourself that it would be no use .Goes to her .I believe it is God 's will that you should not flee with me . I have told you how beautiful it can be in the hills , but all the terrors I have not told you of — the sand-storms , when the whole plain seems to be on fire , the nights as long as a whole winter , and the hunger stealing close to you like an evil mist . You might have come to hate me .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I will hear nothing of all that .Under her breath in terror .They are coming !

div.stage: Enter Bjørn and the District Judge , followed by a crowd of peasants and farm hands . Others come in as the action proceeds .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: pointingThere stands the man .

sp.speaker: The Judge
sp.p: goes to KariYou say your name is Kari .Shows the letter .According to this letter , your name is Eyvind , and you are an escaped thief .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: That is a lie .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: Read the letter .

div.stage: The Judge gives him a sharp look . He opens the letter and reads to himself , now and then raising his eyes from the letter to Kari 's face .

sp.speaker: A Peasant
sp.p: in a low voiceWhat does the judge say ?

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: In the early spring , a man came here who knew himpointingas an escaped thief . I wrote to have the case looked up , and yesterday I got the answer .

sp.speaker: The Judge
sp.p: The description fits you . It is my duty under the law to take you into custody .

sp.speaker: First Peasant
sp.p: I never should have believed it .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: It is the bailiff to whom this letter was sent . May I be allowed to ask where it came from ?

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: From the southland where you were born .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: I was born in the east and have never been south .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: Will the judge look at the seal ?

sp.speaker: The Judge
sp.p: The seal is correct .To Halla .He is in your service . Have you found this man to be a thief ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: No . He has shown himself a trustworthy and an able man .To the people .Do n't you believe , as I do , that Kari is innocent ?

sp.speaker: The Crowd
sp.p: murmuringYes , yes !

sp.speaker: The Judge
sp.p: I cannot judge this case . I must send him to the district where Eyvind 's home is .To Halla .Can you vouch for him a few days ? At present I cannot well spare two men for the journey .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I am not afraid to do that .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: It seems to me unwise to set a woman to watch a thief . If the judge wishes it , I will take him into safe-keeping myself .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Does the bailiff think he can give counsel to the judge ? I offer my farm as surety for Kari .

sp.speaker: The Judge
sp.p: interrupting Bjørn , who is about to replySilence !To Halla .Exit .Then you are responsible .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: I must say that the former judge was not wont to delay the law .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: to the peasantsYou came here to listen to false charges , but you shall have a better pastime . You shall see the bailiff himself play at glima with the man he calls thief .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: You must be crazy ! I wo n't touch him .

sp.speaker: Halla
