sp.p: My dear brother-in-law made me a promise last spring that he would wrestle with Kari here at the folds . It was a wager , and now he is backing out of it . What do you say to that ?

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: An honest man does not play with a thief .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: He is no more thief than you are . Should you be a thief , because I said so ?To the people .He is only too glad to get out of the glima . He is a coward ! He is a coward !

div.stage: Loud or suppressed laughter all around .

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: Never before has Bjørn Bergsteinsson been called a coward .Takes off his coat .

div.stage: Kari throws off his coat . The crowd draws back , leaving an open space . The “ glima ” begins . Bjørn pushes Kari out to the back , and the people follow . The heads of the wrestlers are seen ; then they disappear to the left . A moment of silence , then a sudden outcry .

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: Kari has won ! Kari has won !Silence again .Exeunt some of the crowd .Bjørn is hurt !

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: I think he has had enough .Goes to Halla .

sp.speaker: A Peasant
sp.p: Bjørn had his leg broken . We must help him .

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: I told them to look out for the rocks .

lg.l: It was the bailiff who drew Kari out on the rocks .
lg.stage: Exeunt the rest of the peasants .
lg.l: Bjørn 's voice is heard , threatening . You shall pay me back for this ,

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: I am glad he got it .

sp.speaker: Arngrim
sp.p: “ Hard upon hard , ” said the old woman ; she sat down on a stone .

sp.speaker: The Boy
sp.p: goes to Kari , almost weepingYou are not a thief !

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: patting him on the headNo , no !

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: to ArnesWill you do me the favor to see that my sheep are driven home to-night ? I do n't want Kari to stay here any longer .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: I will do it gladly .To Kari .I meant to warn you against what has overtaken you now .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: I know it . You meant well .

sp.speaker: The Boy
sp.p: May I go home with Kari ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: No , you must stay here and help Arnes . I will go home with Kari myself .Laughs .You know I must watch my prisoner . You may bring the horses , the black and the sorrel .

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: Why all this hurry ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: goes to herYou always had a liking for the little box where my husband kept his money . When we get home , I want you to have that box and all that is in it .

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: But you keep your own money there !

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Not all . I meant to buy quite a number of sheep here to-day .

sp.speaker: Gudfinna
sp.p: on her way outI must be getting old . I do n't understand anything any more .

lg.l: You need not tell them up at the folds that I am going home .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: to ArngrimWe had better be off , too .

sp.speaker: Arngrim
sp.p: goes to KariIf you should happen to ride astray , take care you do n't lose her in the mist .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: to HallaWhat do you mean by riding home now ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Thank God , we have good horses ! The folks wo n't get home with the sheep before nightfall , and they will not begin to look for us until to-morrow . By that time we shall have a good start .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: You must not flee with me , Halla . You do n't know the life you are going to .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: You are a great child . Do n't you think that I have weighed it all ?Smiles .If you wo n't let me come and live with you , I will marry the bailiff .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: kneeling before herHalla !

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: stands for a moment in silence ; takes a long breathTo-night we two shall ride alone in the hills !

div.head: ACT III

stage.stage: A small grass-grown plot . In the foreground , to the right , a fantastic lava formation , a hollow cone five yards in height and three yards in circumference , once an enormous lava bubble produced by gases in the liquid lava . In course of time , the roof has crumbled , also the nearest wall . The farther wall is still standing , but there is a hole in it , through which the sky can be seen . Farther back and somewhat to the left , the wall of a small hut is seen , though partly hidden by the lava formation . The hut is built of stone , the walls of small stones chinked with sod , the roof of large lava slabs . To the left , a deep gorge , the farther wall of which is so much higher than the one near by that it completely shuts off the view to the left . At the bottom of the gorge , a stream . Farther up , the gorge makes a turn to the left , and here the upper part of a waterfall is seen . Behind this , the glacier . On the grass plot is a hearth with a smouldering fire . Some rocks covered with skins serve as seats . From the gorge comes the murmuring sound of the waterfall .
The stage is empty . A horn is heard , first a short call , then a longer .

Enter Kari and Arnes . They are weather-beaten , bareheaded , dressed in knitted jerkins and knitted knee-breeches . Their feet are bare in their shoes . Both have ram 's horns hanging at their side . Kari carries a swan , Arnes a bunch of ptarmigans , some faggots , and a few tufts of bearberry .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: looking into the hutHalla ! No , she is not here .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: She may have gone for water .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: lays down the swanIt is quite heavy .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: You might have let me carry it . I had not tired myself with running .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: As I had caught it , I wanted to carry it .Smiles .The old pride , you see .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: The honor would have been yours just the same .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: This is the first swan this fall .Stroking it fondly .I am glad the feathers did n't get blood-stained .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: It would be lonesome up here if we were only two .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Indeed it would , but you have tried the loneliness before . Was it not two years you had been alone before you met us ?

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: Two and a half .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: pleasedDo you know what we 'll do ? We 'll hide the swan and say that we 've come home empty-handed .Takes the swan .Hand me the ptarmigans .Hides them behind the hut .Now I wish Halla would come soon .Walks to the back and blows his horn .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: is heard answeringHello !

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Here she comes .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: You are a happy mortal .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Yes , I am happy , and it is good to be here . We are free . We have enough to eat . We have sunshine , water , and shelter . What more do you want ?Arnes is silent .I know you are brooding over something you do n't want to tell me . You seem more gloomy every day . Are you longing to get away from here ?

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: Do n't let us talk about such things to-day .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Perhaps it would do you good to unburden yourself to me or , better still , to Halla . She is wiser than I am , and she cares a good deal for you , I tell you .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: There are not many like Halla .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: hastilyWe wo n't tell Halla about the mist . It might frighten her .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: I 'll hold my peace .

div.stage: Enter Halla , carrying a pail of water . The pail is of plaited willow twigs chinked with clay . With the other hand she leads a little girl about three years old . Halla is dressed in a white jerkin and black skirt , both of knitted wool . She wears her silver girdle around her waist . The child has on white knitted clothes . They are bare-headed , and their foot-wear is the same as that worn by the men .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Did you have good luck to-day ?

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: dolefullyWe have caught nothing but trouble and weariness . The ptarmigans made themselves scarce to-day . We saw a flock of six , but they flew away before we could get our snares out .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: to ArnesIs it true , what he says ?

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: It 's true enough . We saw six ptarmigans , but they got away from us .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I am sorry . We must hope for better luck next time .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: laughingI fooled you that time !Runs toward the hut .Look here ! Five big , fat ptarmigans !

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Well , well !

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: holding up the swanAnd that 's all .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: What a lovely surprise ! How did you catch it ?

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: I ran it down .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: I do n't believe there are many who can beat him at that . I know I can n't .

sp.speaker: Tota
sp.p: May Tota pat it ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Tota may do anything she wants to . I should like to make you a jacket of swan 's down .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: cuts off the feet of the swanYou would like these , would n't you ?

sp.speaker: Tota
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Some day when I have time I will skin them and make little bags for you to keep your pebbles in .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: You 've got lovely playthings there !Squats down on the ground .Where are mother 's eyes ?Hiding her eyes with the swan 's feet .

sp.speaker: Tota
sp.p: takes them away from her eyesHere !

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: risingDid you eat all your food ?

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Every bite .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Then you can n't be hungry .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: And it is too early for the evening meal , but I can make you some tea .

lg.l: Let us carry the swan to the cave .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Now Tota must be tied , so the waterfall can n't take her , while mother is making tea .Takes a rope that is fastened to a rock and ties it around Tota 's waist . Brings some of her playthings .Here are all your horses .Puts a kettle of water over the fire ; places some earthenware cups on the rocks by the hearth ; takes a handful of dried herbs from a bag , rinses them in cold water , and portions them out in the cups . The faggots Arnes has brought , she throws on the fire . As she works , she sings .Have you seen a brave young lad ? ‘ Tis my friend , Dearest friend ; ‘ Mongst all men in byrnie clad The bonniest is he . I have smiled my teeth all white and shining , I have smiled my teeth all white and shining with glee . Have you heard his voice 's call , Call of love , Song of love ? O'er my heart the sound did fall And hushed its quick desire . He has kissed my lips all red and glowing , He has kissed my lips all red and glowing as fire . There ! Now we must get the water to boil .Picks up the tufts of bearberry and goes to Tota .See what Arnes brought you !

sp.speaker: Tota
sp.p: They are berries .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Yes , but you must not eat them or you will get a pain in your little stomach .Rises and finds a long , stiff straw .Now I 'll show you what you can do .Threading the berries on the straw , she counts .One , two — four — six , seven — so many years your father and mother have been in the hills .Strokes Tota 's hair .When you are sixteen , we shall have lived here for twenty years , and then we shall be free again . On that day , Tota shall wear snow-white clothes and shoes of colored leather , and mother will clasp her silver girdle around your waist . And when we come down to the lowlands , the first one we meet is a young man with silver buttons in his coat . He stops and turns his horse and stands looking after you ever so long . Then your mother has grown old and wrinkled , and her hair is almost as white as snow . Your father , too , has grown old . But you are straight as a silver-weed , and when you run , you lift your feet high !

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: laughingAh , now it 's steaming . I nearly fell headlong into the cave , when we lifted the cover from the entrance .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Did you ?Gives the straw to Tota .Now you can go on by yourself .Rises .Is there any need of closing the cave every time ? When it 's not raining , it might be left open .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: No harm in being careful . If they should come upon us suddenly , we surely should not have time to close the entrance , and they would find the cave and destroy all our stores , as they did five years ago . Do you remember when we came back to the old place and found nothing but ashes ?— and winter setting in . Not a single piece of mutton did they leave us .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I do n't easily forget .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Whenever I think of it , I feel like doing something wicked . After all , we are human too .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: laughing coldlyWe 're only the foxes who take their sheep .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: to ArnesHow did you hide your stores when you were alone ?

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: I had many hiding-places . Once I stole some twenty-eight pounds of butter . I stuffed it down into a fissure in a rock .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: That was pretty shrewd .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Did you have a clear outlook from the mountain this afternoon ?

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Yes . There was a little mist far to the southward .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: It was from the south that the cloud came in my dream .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: You can never forget about that dream .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I counted fourteen men who came riding out of the cloud .Silent for a moment .You are quite sure the two men whose tracks you saw a month ago did not get on our trail ?

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Quite sure . If they had , they would have come closer .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Just think if they had seen smoke and told about it down in the parish !

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: They have done nothing of the kind ; for if they had , they would have been up here with many men long ago . Ah , the water is boiling .

div.stage: Halla lifts the kettle from the fire and pours water over the herbs .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Your tea will soon be giving out .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Yes , I must take a day and gather enough for the winter . I will go down to the Sun Valley . Nowhere else are the herbs so fine .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Do n't forget to lay in a store of herbs for your salve . You know how troublesome a little scratch can be , when the cold gets into it . You kept the honey I found ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I did .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: That is good for wounds , too . And you must gather cotton grass for lamp wicks .Goes to Tota and gives her tea .Tota must have a taste , too .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: has been looking at HallaYour hair was quite black before , but now there has come a sheen of red into it .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: I have not noticed it , but your freckles are all gone , I have seen that .Patting her cheek .Are you going to give us more tea ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: As much as you want . Karirises and goes into the hut ; returns with three wooden pipes and two pouches , one large and one small .You need not be saving of the leaves , but the tobacco I shall have to dole out to you .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: smilingIt was foolish of you to teach me to smoke .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Why should n't you have that boon as well as I ?Shakes his bag .You need not be shy , I have more in the cave , and when winter sets in and the snow is fit for skiing , we 'll take Arnes down to my brother 's . He promised to lay in good stores of tobacco and salt , and I will pay him with wool , as I did last time .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: If only you do n't end by being caught on one of those journeys !

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Never !They sit smoking in silence .Now I am just in the mood to listen to a good story . Have you one to tell us ?

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: risingNo , I have not .Goes toward the gorge .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: It does not matter if you have told it before .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Arnes may be saving them for the winter .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: rises ; lays down his pipeDo you know what you should do ? Have a good talk with Arnes . I believe he is getting restless and thinks of leaving us .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I hope not .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: I will go and take a bath . You can speak better to him alone , and I need to wash off the sweat .Sings on his way out .Far in the hills I wandered ; softly shone the summer night , And the sun had ne'er a thought of sleeping . Now will I bring my sweetheart dear the hidden treasure bright , For faithfully my vows I would be keeping . Heigh , ho ! New and fine my stockings are , new and fine my shoes , And not a care in all the world to plague me !

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: sits silentIs time hanging heavy on you up here ?

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: goes to herNo , that is only something Kari has got into his head , because I am not always merry .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: smilingOnce you boasted of being kin to the trolls .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: So I am .Halla rises ; blows a great puff of smoke into his face ; laughs . Arnes takes hold of her wrists .Once there were two trolls . They quarrelled and turned each other into stone . One had to stand where all the birds dropped their filth , and the other had to stand where all the winds blew . Which would you rather be ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: tears herself awayI have not been turned to stone yet .Laughs .I thought you had forgotten all your old stories .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: You are strong .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: sits down on the grass , leaning on her armCan you foretell things from the clouds ?

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: Yes , about the weather .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I do n't mean that .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: sits down beside herWhen I was a child , I used to sail my viking ships on the clouds . Do you want me to foretell your fate ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: You just said that you could not .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: The clouds tell nothing about our lives . They are only the dreamlands of earth . Will you let me see your arm ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: lifts her armYou think these lines on your arm are nothing but marks drawn by heather and grass , but if I knew enough , I could read your whole fate in them . Something , perhaps , I can see . Who would believe that these slender arms could be so strong .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: laughingAnd what stands written there ?

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: You must sit still . Here is a deep , narrow line across your arm , that means sorrow . And there is a big fire .Stroking her arm with the tips of his fingers .I can see the tongues of flame . That means that you are loved .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: stands up ; laughsDid you burn yourself ?

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: I should like to read your fate all day long .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Then you might tell me things I did not care to hear . But I must get to work .

div.stage: Halla goes into the hut . Arnes looks after her . She comes out bringing wool , a spindle , and a sheep 's skin .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: If you are not too tired after the hunt , this skin can stand a little more .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: Give it to me .Takes a large ring made of a ram 's horn . From the ring hangs a loop of rope , in which he puts his foot . He draws the skin through the ring and keeps pulling it back and forth . Halla sits down , turning her spindle . They are silent .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: It is queer about the sound of the waterfall . Most of the time I do n't hear it at all , but if it were to stop , I should miss it . Is it the same with you ?

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: At first I was almost afraid of it . Then I began to love it , and now I should only miss it if it were not there any more . We mortals are strange .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: Can you tell me why some people should be happier than others ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: No , that I cannot .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: Kari has been happy for seven years .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Are you sure of that ?

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: Why should he not be happy ? He has a wife and child .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Was there no one down your way whom you could bring with you up here ?

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: Who do you think would become an outlaw for my sake ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Would n't you dare to carry off a woman ? I should try my best to be good to her .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: Do you think Kari would have dared to carry you off against your will ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Ask him .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: Why does he not show it , if he cares so much for you ? He forgets about helping you with firewood and carrying water , and if the meat is not cooked the way he likes it , he scolds you . One might think you were his servant girl .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Do n't let that worry you .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: And he can n't even see the color of your hair .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Do you bear a grudge against Kari , because he caught the swan ?

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: You had house and home and a good name , and you gave it all up for his sake . He ought to keep that in mind more than he does .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I do n't want Kari to be offering up thanks like a meek bondsman . Besides , I have done nothing for him . I did it all for myself .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: He does not even bother to curry the skins for your bedding . If you did not have me , you would have to do it yourself .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: stands upI do n't want your help .Takes hold of the skin .Let go !

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: gives it up reluctantlyAre you angry ? Hallatakes the skin out of the horn-ring and throws it into the hutYou are not so sorely needed as you think you are .Sits down again to her work .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: I did not mean that . It makes me happy when I can do some little thing for you . Wo n't you let me finish it ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: You shall not touch it .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: stands for a moment , puzzledWill you not forgive me what I said ? I cannot bear to have you angry with me .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I am not angry .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: When you were ill , I once brought you some green leaves that had come up through the snow . Then you gave me a kiss .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Did I ?Smiles ; kisses him lightly on the cheek .Have you peace in your soul now ?

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: I do n't know . I believe I shall never have peace in my soul any more .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: You were good to me the time I was ill .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: I am not good to anybody . I am wicked .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: You are not .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: Even with you I sometimes feel that I could hurt you .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: We can all be ugly when we are tired and hungry .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: Will you let me kiss your mouth ? Just once ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: risingNo .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: Your lips will suffer no harm from it .Takes hold of her shoulders and tries to draw her to him .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: tears herself away from himHave you gone mad ?

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: You have been true to Kari for seven years now . It is time you tired of it .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Now your face looks like the bailiff 's when he called me a harlot .Gives him a box on the ear .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: furiouslyI know you better than you think . You are so pure ! You have never done an evil deed !

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: Kari is more open-mouthed than you think . You have had a child before this one .

div.stage: Halla shields her face with her hands as though warding off a blow . Arnes sits silent .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Why do n't you say that I killed my child ? That is what you meant to say . You know I did it .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: My cursed mouth .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: You judge me . How can you ? You do n't know what it means to bring a life into the world . It grows heavier day by day like the snow of winter . If we had had spring and sunshine ! But the times were hard and food was scarce . I did a good deed when I laid my child out in the cold . Far less suffering that than life !

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: I do not judge what you did .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: No , you thought I was an angel who was longing to be your harlot . You can go with a lighted candle into my soul and search it . You will find no remorse there . What could we have done with a child , if we had been forced to flee ? Should we have left it with strangers ? And how do you think it would have fared ? A child of felons , scorned by all ! Arnesbroken-heartedI did not know that my words would hurt you so much .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Do you think I did it with a light heart ? I have given birth to two children , and cruel was the pain , but I would rather bear ten children than live that night over again . When I had carried my child out into the cold , my mind gave way . In my ravings , I thought the child lay by my side , and above us was a flock of birds — pitch black . I bent over it to shield it , and the birds pecked into my back , into my lungs they pecked .Stops short from emotion .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: Would I were dead !

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: calmerI wished for the death of that child long before it was born .Goes to Tota .But this my little springtime child I have never wished ill . The first time I felt her life , it seemed a token of forgiveness that I was allowed to become a mother again , and when she came into the world , the sun was shining , and the sky was blue and warm .Kisses her .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: My tongue got the better of me .Puts his hand on his heart .There is a devil dwelling in me .Stands motionless .I love you .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: turns toward himHave you not done hurting me yet ?

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: crushedNo matter what I say , you think I mean ill .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I shall not speak to you again .Sits down to her work .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: Nor will you have to listen to me any more . I am going down to the lowlands , and there they can do with me what they like .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: If you tell them of our hiding-place , they may let you off more easily .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: Even that you believe I could do !

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: risingIf you cared for me as much as you say , you would be good to me instead of bad .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: Love has made you good and me bad .He is silent .Do you remember the time Kari and I went up the glacier , and he fell down into a crack ? He told you I had been so frightened that I shook all over . It was not for his life I feared ; I feared my own thoughts .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: terrified by a dawning apprehensionWhat do you mean ?

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: I have often wished Kari dead .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: It is not true !

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: It is . Do you understand now that I must go away from here ? I no longer dare to live with you two , and neither do I dare to live alone .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I wish you had never crossed our path .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: following up his own thoughtsIf Kari had not been so trusting as he is , I do n't know what I might not have done ; but he had such faith in me . You do n't know all the words the Tempter can whisper in one 's ear . I thought Kari had been happy so long that it would be only fair if he had to die now . It seemed to me that you and I were more akin in our souls , that we had more of the wilds in us . I felt it was he alone that stood between us two .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I forbid you to say another word . All your thoughts are lies . If Kari had died , I should have followed him . You would have had my corpse , not me . And if I had learned that you were the cause of his death , I should have killed you while you were asleep . I have given my all to my husband , even my conscience . I can go on living , even if he should not always care so much for me , but when I no longer love him , then I die .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: I am glad you love your husband . I do n't know whether it is because I have unburdened myself of all my evil thoughts , or whether it is because I have made up my mind to give myself up and serve my time , but I feel a peace within me that I have not known for long . To-morrow I shall go away from here and never come back . I shall tell Kari that I mean to take a short trip .Goes to Halla .Will you do the last thing I ask of you in this life — never to let him know the truth ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I can make you no promise .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: Then I will bid you good-bye while we are alone . I shall cross the lava strip and sit down where I can look out over the sand waste . You may tell Kari that I shall be back in an hour .Holding out his hand .Is there no hope that you can ever think of me without bitterness when I am gone ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: takes his handGood-bye , Arnes .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: Good-bye , Halla .Walks a few steps ; stops .Exit .When I am sitting within prison walls , I shall remember you as the most beautiful thing I have ever seen .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: stands looking after him ; then goes to TotaWhat a good , quiet little girl you are ! Getting sleepy ?Finds a small skin , which she spreads on the ground .Now mother will sing you to sleep , as she did in the old times .Unfastens the rope .Shall I , Tota ?

sp.speaker: Tota
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: sits down and takes her on her lapThen you must close your eyes .Sits silent , then hums as she rocks the child .Sweetly sleep , my dear young love , Outside rain is falling . Mother safely away will stow Horse and sheep and swan and dove . Then we 'll rest , we two , for night is calling . Darkness spreads o'er many a woe , Sore hearts , broken pledges . Meadows green laid waste I saw , Scythe of sand the field did mow , Death calls from the glacier 's cruel ledges . Are you asleep ?She rises slowly , lays the child on the skin , and covers her up , then sits down to her work .

div.stage: Enter Kari , his hair wet from the bath .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Do you know what I have a mind to do ?

lg.l: You must not speak too loud . Tota is asleep .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: I 'll be right back .Disappears down the gorge . A moment later he comes into view again .Some day when I feel good and strong I have a mind to try to swim against the current all the way into the inner ravine . From here I should look like a dwarf down there .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: risingArnes went out on the sands . He will be back in about an hour . He has made up his mind to start on a trip to the southland to-morrow .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: I knew he was longing to get away from here . I only hope he will not come to harm !

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: goes to himIf he should never come back , we two should be alone , as we were in the old days .Takes his hands .Do you care a little for me yet ?

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: You know I do .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I feel that I need to hear you say it .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: holding her handsAnd I show it far too seldom . I forget . You must tell me when there is anything you want me to do .Kisses her ; releases her hands .Are you sorry that Arnes is going ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: You never saw the queer little brook I found once . It welled out from a moss-covered hillock and ran in a ring . Where it flowed the banks were green , but elsewhere there was nothing but sand . Its whole course was no longer than what I could walk in thirty steps . It seems to me that life is like that stream .

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: in a whisperThey 're coming !

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: terrifiedWhat ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: goes to ArnesAre you trying to scare us ?

sp.speaker: Arnes
sp.p: They 'll be here in a minute . I counted nine . You must flee at once ! There 's no time to lose .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I wo n't run away from Tota .

lg.l: We stand no chance , three against nine . You must leave her with them .
There they are ! For God 's sake , run !
lg.stage: Halla is on the point of running .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: startled , stopsIt 's Bjørn !A terrible expression as of madness darkens her features . She seizes Tota ; her voice is harsh and unnatural .The cub he shall not have !

sp.speaker: Tota
sp.p: frightened and sleepyMother !

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: runs sobbing to the gorgeTota ! Tota ! Tota !Disappears .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: who has remained inert and dumb with terror runs afterWhat are you doing ?

div.stage: From the gorge is heard the scream of a child , which is suddenly silenced . Halla comes up again .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Halla ! Halla ! Bjørn 's voicevery nearMake haste !

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: shrieks to himDevil !

sp.speaker: Bjørn
sp.p: grabbing HallaNow I 've got you !

div.stage: Kari seizes his knife and stabs Bjørn through the heart . Bjørn falls dead . Kari and Halla flee . Bjørn 's men enter , stand as though paralyzed at the sight of the slain man . Arnes goes slowly up to them .

div.head: ACT IV

stage.stage: A small hut in the hills . Two large stones covered with skins serve as seats . The low bedstead is also covered with skins . On the wall hang some poor , clumsy tools . In the slanting roof , a small window is darkened with snow . On the hearth , a low fire . Outside , a snowstorm . Now and then , snow comes whirling down the smoke-hole .
Kari is pacing to and fro , beating his arms . Halla sits silent . They are both dressed in skins .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Are you cold ?

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: I do n't know .Halla rises and puts some faggots on the fire . Kari takes a stick from the wall ; counts .I need n't count the notches . This is the seventh day the snowstorm is raging without a break , and it is past Easter . How long do you think it can keep on ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: It 's no use asking me about it .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: replaces the stick in the wallIf the walls were not frozen so hard , the storm would have torn down the hut long ago .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: It is bound to stop sometime .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: You think so ? It 's four years now since that terrible summer when the sun was red and dim from morning till night .In secret awe .There may come a summer when the sun does not rise at all .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: It was the ashes that made the sun look so red that summer .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: I could well live a whole summer without the sun , if I only had food .Picks up a big knife .This fellow has not tasted meat in a whole eternity .A rapturous ring comes into his voice .I remember a ram I once killed ; he was so fat he could hardly walk .Plants himself in front of Halla .If he stood there now , bodily , should you have strength enough to hold his feet for me ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I think I should .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: We should have to take care not to be too greedy . If we could only hold back the first two days , we might eat as much as we wanted afterward .His mouth waters ; he swallows saliva .You have seen a butchered sheep hung up to dry in the wind ; its flesh is as tender as a young girl 's . I feel as though I could fondle it ; I could bite it .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: We have promised each other not to speak of food .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: And how do you think the heart would taste smoking hot from the fire ? I could swallow it in one mouthful . I should feel as if I had eaten , if I could only smell warm meat .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: You will make me sick if you do n't stop talking about food . Do n't you think I am just as hungry as you are ? And I hold my peace .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Yes , you hold your peace .Puts down the knife .If I did not see your eyes , I should think you were dead , and yet you are human and living like myself . Are you not ?Halla is silent .Or perhaps you are a heathen image ? Must I kneel down before you and pray for fine weather ? Shall I build a fire before you and stain your feet with blood ? What do you want ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I want to be left in peace .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: You ought to be a tree , then you could wither in peace . Why do n't you cry out like every living thing that suffers . You do n't know how your calmness racks me . Even the trees cry and moan in the autumn gales — they wail !

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I should wail too , if there was any one that could hear me .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: I do n't care whether anybody hears my screams or not . I 'll scream ; I 'll yell .Yells .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: stands upAre you not ashamed of yourself ?

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: in a weak voiceThis cannot last . I should have gone long ago . I ought to have gone at once , the first day the food gave out , but you thought every day that the morrow would bring fine weather . I know you said it to soothe me , but it was not right .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: It was no use going to certain death .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: I should never be afraid of getting lost . If the snowstorm is ever so dark , I find my way .Raises his hand .I know where I am by trend of the wind .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: If you were so sure of yourself , you ought indeed to have gone long ago .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: hardeningYou say that ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Yes , I say that .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Take care ! You have tempted me to stay day after day . Your believing and hoping palsied my will . You wormed your own fear into my heart and broke my courage . If we both die of hunger , the fault is yours , and yours alone .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Is it my fault ?

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: You have lived in the hills for sixteen years , and you do n't know them more than a child does . Perhaps you think the snowstorm will have pity ? Wo n't you open the door and bid the snowstorm be still ? Why do n't you ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: You say that it is my fault if we starve to death . Who was it that stole ?

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: stands for a moment speechlessYou are homely . I have never before seen how homely you are . Your face makes me think of the head of a dead horse .Reaches out his arms .May I feel of your hair if it does n't all come out ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Do n't touch me ! Karilets his arms fall . An expression of sadness comes into his voiceI thought you were the only one who understood that I could not help what I did . Neither could you help what you have done , and yet you are bringing my misdeeds up against me .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Never before have I upbraided you for this , but you put the whole blame on me .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: And you said it in such a hard tone . It was as if you struck me with stones .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: My voice was no harder than yours .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: It 's becoming in you to chide me , as if you had not yourself urged me to steal many a time !

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Since we became outlawed we have had a right to steal . We had to do it to keep from starving .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: I thought you had forgiven me , and then you have been hoarding your charges . For sixteen years you have kept them , and they have not been corrupted either by rust or moth .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Come now , do n't be angry , Kari . I said it in the heat of temper .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: I am not angry , but it hurt so ! I thought that you would be my spokesman before the Great Judge . If you If could forgive me , He might do it , too .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I did not mean to hurt you . I only said it to defend myself .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: following up his own thoughtsThere are stones in the hills that are blood-stained from my feet ; you must gather those and bring them before the Great Judge .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Wo n't you take to weeping , so I can gather up your tears and bring them before the Great Judge ?

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Are you mocking me ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Yes ; I wo n't listen to your whining any longer . Now we shall sit down and hold our peace .Sits down .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: You shall not be worried by my whining .Takes the fur socks down from the wall ; sits down and unties the straps of his shoes . Halla watches him in silence , while he puts on one sock .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Are you going ?

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: You do n't ask my advice ?

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: No , this time I do n't ask it .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: risingWhen you go out of that door , you need not think of me any more .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: I know your voice when you are angry . You ought to thank me for going out in such weather .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Yes , you are brave . It is not that you have any hope of saving our lives . You will only lie down in the snow and die .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: You can believe it if you like .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: goes to himI beg of you , let those hard words be forgotten .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: It is not because of them that I am going . The worst that can befall me is to die in the snow , and that is better than sitting here .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: First of all , we must use our common sense . The only thing we can do is to wait here until the weather clears .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: And then the food will come flying in through the door !

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Not that , but there will be means of help . We can dig up roots to still the worst hunger , and we can go to the lake for fish .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: The snowstorm may last four or five days yet , and by that time we shall be dead from hunger .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: How long shall you be gone ?

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Two days at the most .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: goes to him and touches his shoulderI beg you to stay for my sake ! We have lived together for sixteen years , and now let us also die together .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: I know your way of hiding your will . Now it is your will that I should stay , but this time you are foiled .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: You cared for me when I fled with you to the hills . You told me there was no one like me in all the world . You carried me across the streams , until I grew strong enough to ford them myself . You risked your life to get the things you knew I liked . Have you forgotten ?

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: I have forgotten nothing .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: And all the nights we slept with the heavens above us ! Was it not blessed to feel the morning breeze over your face and to open your eyes and look into the blue sky ? Then you kissed me and said that you loved me .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: You shall not stop me from going .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: turns away from himI know why I have this fear of being alone . It is because I am so far away from every living thing , and there 's no sun and no stream here .Turns toward him .If we feel that we must die , you can close the smoke-hole , and I will fill the hut with smoke . We shall lie down side by side .Touches his hand .I will take your hand , and we shall dream that we are going out into a sand-storm together .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: harshlyNow leave me in peace .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: in helpless fearI will tell you the truth . I do n't dare to be alone .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Are you afraid of the dark ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: When you are gone , I know I shall begin to listen . I know what I shall hear .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: What do you hear ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I hear the sound of a great heavy waterfall . I hear the screams of my child . You must not leave me .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: turns awayYou spare me nothing ; you make my going as hard as can be .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I forbid you to go ! It 's inhuman to leave me here alone . If you ever come back , you will find me a mad beast .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Now you shall keep still . I will not listen to your whining any longer .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: You are like all the rest . When your will is set , you have no heart .Sits down silently .Karifastens his foot-gear ; ties a rope around his waistWhen I draw it tight enough , I do n't feel that I am hungry .Puts on a coat of heavy fur .You must watch the fire and not let it go out . I 'll bring you some more faggots from the wood-shed .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: stands up ; her voice is huskyBetter kill me before you go .Bares her breast .Stab me with your knife — right here ! I wo n't scream .Shuts her eyes .I shall think I am nursing my child , and the little teeth are biting my breast .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Have you gone mad ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: You have n't the heart , but you have the heart to let me sit here all alone . A wretched little train-oil lamp you would put out before you went ; you could not bear to let it burn over nothing .Sits down .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: stands silent a long timeI have been guilty of many a bad deed , but so far as I know , I have never been cruel . Nor will I be cruel to you .Takes off his coat .Then we shall wait together as you wish . Does that make you feel happier ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I do n't know . I can feel neither joy nor grief any longer . I think I would rather be alone .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: You do n't mean that .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: If you think it wiser to go , you must do so .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: I thought it would make you glad if I stayed .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: risingIf you had taken me in your arms and told me that you loved me with all my wretchedness and all my homeliness , that would have made me glad ; but you did not .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Yet you know it was for your sake I stayed .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Are you so sure of that ? Perhaps you were afraid that you might be guilty of a wrong deed . I think you had in mind the Great Judge rather than me .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: I have once been judged by men ; that is why I so often think of the last judgment .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I will have no talk of conscience between you and me . Be yourself with me , whether you are good or bad . After all , you do n't know if the Great Judge looks kindly at what you call good deeds . Look at me ! Look at me ! You could not be more cruel to your worst enemy . Why was I given this hunger and not the food to still it ? I have never wished to be born . I would rather be anything else than a human being . I would rather be the sand , whirling aimlessly over yonder waste . If there is a God , He must be cruel — but there is no God .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: You are only lashing yourself up . You ought rather to humble yourself and pray God to help both you and me . Without Him we are but dust and ashes .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I want no mercy any more , but you can go on calling for help .Mockingly .I am sure He will hear you , if He is not busy breaking up the glaciers or cleaning out the gorge of a volcano to make it belch up more fire .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Do n't say another word ! We are wretched enough without your calling down new curses upon us .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: I have but one sole and only wish before I die , and that is to do some unheard-of cruel deed . I should like to be a snowslide . I would come in the dead of night . It would be a joy to see the people half naked running for their lives — chaste old maids with gouty hips , and smug peasant women with bellies bobbing with fat .Sits down , breaks into a paroxysm of laughter , wild and continued .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: You have become a monster . I am afraid of you — afraid of the only human being I care for .Walks over to a corner , where he finds his old Bible . Sits down , turning the pages with trembling hands ; reads .“ And it came to pass that as he was praying in a certain place , when he ceased one of his disciples said unto him , Lord , teach us to pray as John also taught his disciples . And he said unto them , When ye pray , say , Our Father which art in heaven , Hallowed be thy name . Thy kingdom come . Thy will be done , as in heaven , so in earth . Give us day by day our daily bread . And forgive us our sins : for we also forgive every one that is indebted to us . And lead us not into temptation ; but deliver us from evil . For thine is the kingdom and the power and the glory for ever . Amen . ”

div.stage: They sit silent a while . Halla , leaning her elbows on her knees , her face buried in her hands , cries softly . Kari rises , stands silent for a moment , then goes to her .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: You must not lose heart . When things are at the worst , they will mend . Perhaps the storm will quiet down during the night .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: It is so hard .Bursts into sobs .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: kneelingBut , dearest Halla ! Are you ill ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: warding him offLet me alone .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: rises slowlyYou were always so strong . I thought nothing could make you lose heart . Hallalooks up . She has stopped crying ; her voice is calm and coldYou do n't love me any more . You have never loved me .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Is that what you are crying for ?

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: Before when you wanted to leave me , I besought you by all the memories I thought were dear to you . That did not touch you . I humbled myself so low that I would have thanked you just for a little pity ,— that might have been an afterglow of your love , but you had no pity . You stayed only because you were anxious about your own soul .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: I stayed also for your sake .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: You know better . You would rather die than have your God find you guilty of an evil deed . You counted the saving of your soul higher than your life , but I have no God , and I have never been able to tell my soul from my love . If you had loved me , you would have understood that I was pleading for my soul . You would have heard it in my voice , but you did not hear it .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: You forget that it was to save our lives I wanted to go . Hallarises . Her eyes are large and burningWhy did you not take me with you ?

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: If I had gone alone , I might have come back alive . The two of us would have been sure to perish .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: kneelsI once dreamed of two people . To them their love was the one and only law . When they had lived a long life together , they were thrown into direst need . Hunger drew near to the fine web that time had woven between them and would tear it asunder . Then they looked into each other 's eyes , and together they walked out into the snowstorm to die .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: It is every man 's duty to keep alive as long as he can .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: risingAnd why should it be , when life has become an agony to ourselves and of use to no one ?

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: It is the law of God .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: The storm writes many laws in the sand .Sits down .When my strength had given out , you could have left me in the snow .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: You know very well that I would never have done that .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: That would have been better than to leave me waiting here . And I do n't believe that death is so hard . The storm carries you until you drop from weariness , and then the snow comes and covers you up .Staring before her with eyes wide open .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: is silent for a momentYou are bitter , because of our sore plight . Many a time have I told myself that I have been the curse of your life . If you had never known me , you would now be living in peace and quiet . You could have ridden to church every Sunday , if you liked . You would have been the rich and comely widow with all the young men flocking about you . I dare say you have often been sorry that you fled with me to the hills .Halla is silent .I remember once we had been out hunting together all night . Early in the morning we stood on the rim of the mountain plain looking down upon the fields and the dwellings of men . On some of the farms , the fires were lighted already , and the smoke rose straight up into the blue air , and the streams ran so quietly and pleasantly through the meadows . I thought then that I could see the homesickness in your eyes .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: starting up , her voice cold and calm againIf I could only have saved my faith in my own love , but I love you no longer , and it may be that I never have loved you . As a child I used to live more in my dreams than in the life about me . When I fled with you to the hills , I thought it was because I loved you , but perhaps it was only my longing for the strange and unknown . Afterwards , when the days became harder and lonelier , my love for you was a shelter which I would seek when sorrow for what I had done came clutching at my heart .

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Say no more ! You are befouling our love — yours and mine . You say it was only a longing for the unknown and the free , unfettered life that made you flee with me to the hills . Shame on you !His voice is soft and full of sadness .I know what you have been . No woman was ever greater in her love than you . When the sun strikes the rim of the glacier , it takes on the loveliest hues , though in truth it is nothing but dull , colorless clay . So your love has been the sunlight in my life , and I love you — have always loved you . When I was away from you even for a single day , I would long to see you and hear your voice as eagerly as I would long for the murmur of a brook when nearly dying from thirst . When I went hunting and had good luck , I always thought of you . When I pictured to myself how pleased you would be , I forgot all about my weariness . But you must not ask the impossible of a man .

sp.speaker: Halla
sp.p: risingI am cold . Will you fetch some wood ?

sp.speaker: Kari
sp.p: Yes , indeed .Goes to the door ; leaves it ajar .You cannot see a hand before you .Goes out and shuts the door after him .

div.stage: Halla goes to the door , listens , opens the door . A cloud of snow comes whirling in . Outside the storm sweeps past . She takes a long , lingering look around the hut , goes out into the doorway , throws her head back , and disappears , carried by the storm .
The stage stands empty for a moment .

sp.speaker: Kari returns , covered with snow , his arms full of faggots
sp.p: Kari . Why do you leave the door open ?Sees that Halla is not there , drops the faggots , goes out hurriedly , calls .Halla !His call is heard outside the hut . He comes back into the doorway , looks in , cries out .Almighty God !Two heart-broken cries are heard outside , the latter farther away and hushed by the storm .Halla ! Halla !

div.stage: The snow comes whirling into the empty hut .

docTitle.titlePart: THE HRAUN FARM [ Gaarden Hraun ] A PLAY IN THREE ACTS

set.p: The action takes place in Iceland . Time , the Present . “ Hraun ” is the Icelandic word for lava-field .

div.head: ACT I

stage.stage: The farm . Five white gables , all adjoining and separated by heavy partitions . The roof is covered with turf , the walls are of earth and stone . The gable farthest to the left is without a door , but has two windows on the ground floor and a smaller window above . The next has a door leading into the “ badstofa ” or servants ’ quarters . The third is a dairy and storehouse ; the fourth , a smithy ; the fifth , a drying-shed . In the yard is a horse-block ; to the left , a picket fence . Before the doors lie the packs unloaded from nine horses : two green chests , sacks of grain and household stuff , lumber , and a number of other articles . Jakobina stands feeling one of the sacks . Helgi is undoing the strappings . The door to the smithy is open . Einar is seen within , forging horseshoe nails .

sp.speaker: It is morning , before breakfast
sp.p: Jakobinatalking half to herselfThis must be coffee .Lays her hand on one of the chests .And what has Jorunn got in these , I wonder ! I fancy there are many pretty things there .

sp.speaker: Helgi
sp.p: You may be sure of that .

sp.speaker: Jakobina
sp.p: Nineteen years I 've been here now , and it 's never happened yet that the mistress has forgotten to bring something or other to please me when she came back from town ,— and it was n't always little things either , God bless her ! Oh , but there they have knocked off the paint . What a shame !Sits down on the chest and runs her hand over the paint .

div.stage: Enter Bjørg and Rannveig from the left , carrying pails full of milk , which they set down .

sp.speaker: Rannveig
sp.p: They brought home quite a bit . We shall not go hungry for a while yet . Where are they ?

sp.speaker: Helgi
sp.p: They are inside , drinking coffee .

sp.speaker: Bjørg
sp.p: Is Jon drunk ?

sp.speaker: Helgi
sp.p: Not so very ; he 's just a little gay .

sp.speaker: The Shepherd Boy
sp.p: Are you through milking already ?

sp.speaker: Bjørg
sp.p: Ca n't you see for yourself ?

sp.speaker: The Shepherd Boy
sp.p: Oh , pshaw !His eyes light on the lumber piles . He bends down and begins to count the knots in the wood .One , two , three —

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: What do you say , girls ? Quite a pack , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: Bjørg
sp.p: I should say so !

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: to HelgiYou 've begun to undo the strappings ? That 's fine . And here come the others .

div.stage: Enter Jon and Indridi from the house . Jon is somewhat intoxicated .

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: Here stands our dear master . Good day to you , Rannveig ! Good day !

sp.speaker: Bjørg and Rannveig
sp.p: Good day , and welcome home !

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: laughingWhy do n't you put your arms around the girls and give them a kiss ? Are you afraid ?

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: No , Jon is n't afraid .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Runs into the house .You did n't get anything with your coffee .

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: He is the same as ever .

div.stage: Bjørg and Rannveig carry the milk into the store-house .

sp.speaker: Jakobina
sp.p: risingYou did n't take notice of anything in particular on your way back ?

sp.speaker: Indridi
sp.p: Not that I remember .

sp.speaker: Jakobina
sp.p: Did you see many birds ?

sp.speaker: Indridi
sp.p: Come to think of it , I do n't believe I saw any .

sp.speaker: Jakobina
sp.p: Goes into the house .That 's what I thought .

div.stage: Enter Sveinungi from the house with a flask and a glass , which he fills .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Here , this is for you .

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: drinksThanks .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: fills the glass again for Indridi and HelgiWo n't you take a drop too , Einar ?

sp.speaker: Einar appears in the doorway of the smithy
Sveinungi
sp.p: sees the Shepherd BoyAre you here ? Why , the girls are all through milking . Do you suppose you can keep the sheep standing in the fold all day ?The Shepherd Boy is about to go .Wait a minute ! I have a little thing here that I bought for you yesterday .Takes a knife from his vest pocket .I think the blade is good iron , and that is the main thing .Gives him the knife . The Shepherd Boy kisses him .It is not much . You are welcome to it .

sp.speaker: The Shepherd Boy
sp.p: opens the knifeLook , Einar , it 's a regular hunting-knife .Closes it , runs to the left , calling .Snati ! Pila ! Snati !

sp.speaker: Rannveig
sp.p: You need n't call the dogs . They are up at the fold .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: That boy will amount to something in time . It 's well done for one so young to tend more than four-score sheep , and he has n't lost one yet .

div.stage: Takes the flask back to the house .

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: He 's in mighty good humor to-day , the old man .

sp.speaker: Bjørg
sp.p: I should say so .

sp.speaker: Indridi
sp.p: Why , he got the highest price for his wool .

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: And a sorry day it would be when we did n't get that !

sp.speaker: Indridi
sp.p: What do you think Jakobina had in mind when she asked about the birds ?

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: It 's hard to tell ! She has her mind on so many things .

div.stage: Enter Sveinungi and Jorunn from the house .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: in the door , laughing and talkingIndridi goes with one of the chests .I believe the girls have their eye on the green chests . Indridi , will you carry them in ?

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: You can put them in the little room .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Rannveig , will you bring me the key to the drying-shed ? You know where it hangs .Rannveig runs in .You boys will have to carry the breadstuffs up into the loft of the storehouse , and the coffee and sugar too , and while I think of it , you had better take one sack out to the mill , Helgi .

sp.speaker: Helgi
sp.p: I will .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: opening a bagHere , Einar , you 'll find iron and nails and brazil-wood , and here 's something for yourself .Hands him a plug of tobacco .See if you can be a bit saving of it .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: pats him on the shoulderGod bless you !

sp.speaker: Rannveig
sp.p: comes outHere is the key . Sveinungiunlocks the door to the drying-shedYou can stack the timber on top of the old pile . After you have had your breakfast , you , Jon , and Indridi had better go and lie down . You must be tired .

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: I am sure I could keep on working all day if need be , and just as hard as those who have had their sleep .Indridi comes for the other chest .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: laughsThere are not many like you .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: Where is Ljot ? I thought she was here .

sp.speaker: Helgi
sp.p: I saw her walking in the yard . I have not seen her come back .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: goes to the picket fence ; callsLjot !

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: is heard answeringYes !

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Are you there ? Are n't you coming home ?

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: is heard answeringI am coming .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: Have you set the milk ?

sp.speaker: Rannveig
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: Then come in , if you want to see what I have bought . Einarsteps out into the door of the smithy . He holds a snuff-box in his hand , and is rolling up a long plug of tobacco , which he puts into the boxThis tastes better ; the old stuff was getting as dry as hay .Spits .Oh , well , there was a time , but that 's so long ago .

sp.speaker: Helgi
sp.p: What are you talking about ?

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: It was a winter night , and I was lying in wait for the fox . Well , what happened was neither more nor less than this , that when I wanted to take a chew of tobacco , I found I 'd left the box at home . I can stand it for one night , I thought , but it was cold where I was lying , and the fox made himself scarce . Let me tell you , when I had been waiting till nearly dawn , I 'd gladly have given my soul for a good honest chew .

div.stage: Ljot passes through from the right , carrying some freshly gathered flowers in her hand . Goes into the house .

sp.speaker: Helgi
sp.p: And did you get the fox ?

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: I did . It came just as I was about to go home .

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: When you got home , I 'm sure you went straight for a good big plug of tobacco .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: Maybe I did ! It was the finest blue fox I 've ever shot .

div.stage: Enter Frida from the left . She is warm from running .

sp.speaker: Frida
sp.p: Now I 've turned the horses out on the grass .Wipes her forehead .Do you want me to pull the bellows for you ?

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: Frida runs in .You 'd better go in and see if Jorunn should happen to have something for you . Then you can come back here .

div.stage: Enter Bjørg and Rannveig from the house .

sp.speaker: Bjørg
sp.p: See what the mistress has brought for me !Holding up a piece of cloth .It will be fun to make that into an apron .

sp.speaker: Rannveig
sp.p: I got a head-kerchief with red flowersholds it upand a piece of soap .Smells it .

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: May I ?Smells it .You 'll be good to kiss , when you have washed with that soap .

sp.speaker: Rannveig
sp.p: Only I wo n't let you .

sp.speaker: Thora
sp.p: in the doorwayI must show you what I got , too .

div.stage: Enter Sølvi from the left , carrying a gun over his shoulder and a small knapsack on his back .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: Good day to you !

sp.speaker: The Servants
sp.p: Good day !

sp.speaker: Indridi
sp.p: We did not see you coming .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: I took the short cut . May I have something to drink ? I am thirsty .

sp.speaker: Rannveig
sp.p: I 'll get it for you .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: lowering his voiceAnd may I see Ljot for a moment ? I have something for her .

sp.speaker: Rannveig
sp.p: Exeunt Girls .I 'll tell her .

sp.speaker: Indridi
sp.p: Have you any news ?

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: Indridi
sp.p: You are still at Hol ?

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: Indridi
sp.p: Have they begun to cut the hay ?

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: Not yet .

sp.speaker: Indridi
sp.p: They generally start before any of the other farms .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: They need to . They do n't keep much help .

sp.speaker: Rannveig
sp.p: Here it is , and you are welcome to it .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: drinksThanks .

sp.speaker: Rannveig
sp.p: Goes in .I have told Ljot .

sp.speaker: Helgi
sp.p: Here , give me a hand !Indridi lifts the sack to Helgi 's back ; Helgi carries it out to the left .

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: coiling the last ropesWe can start carrying the lumber into the shed .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: Good day to you , Ljot !

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: Good day ! You wished to see me ?

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: You wo n't be angry with me ?— I thought perhaps you would like this .Takes the skin of a duck from his knapsack .I shot it on the creek the other day , and I thought it was so pretty that I took off the skin and dried it . Do you think you could make use of it — say for a riding-cap ?

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: It is beautiful .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: When you hold the wing this way the spot is blue , and when you hold it so it is green ; it 's the way the light falls .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: I doubt if I dare take it . I scarcely know you .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: You would make me very happy if you would take it .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: Then I will , and thank you .Gives him her hand .How lovely it is !

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: lowering his voiceDo you never go for a walk by yourself in the hraun ?

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: Why do you ask ?

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: You know the pretty spot by the old roan tree ; it is not more than a good ten minutes ’ walk from here . I thought perhaps you might go there sometimes on Sundays .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: blushesI do n't know —

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: I shall be there all day Sunday . Good-bye , Ljot .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: confusedGood-bye .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: Exit to the left .I shall be there at sunrise , and I shall be there when the sun goes down .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Who was it that went just now ?

sp.speaker: Indridi
sp.p: Is he gone ? It was Sølvi .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: What did he want here ?

sp.speaker: Indridi
sp.p: He got a cup of milk .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: to LjotIt seemed to me he was talking to you . What have you there ?

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: He gave me a bird 's skin .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Pshaw ! You should have made him keep it himself .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: There was no harm meant .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Einar could have brought you down one just like it , if you had cared for it . Why are you blushing so ?

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: I did not think you would be so angry because I took the bird 's skin .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: I can n't bear him , that stone-picker ! He roves from place to place like a tramp . Let him dare to set his nets for you ! Give me the creature , and I 'll hand it back to him next time he comes ; for he 's sure to come .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: Goes in .I can burn it myself , if you grudge me the keeping it .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: talking in the doorwayAnd then you get angry to boot .To Indridi .I see you have undone all the strappings .

sp.speaker: Indridi
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Where is Helgi ?

sp.speaker: Indridi
sp.p: He went to the mill .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Goes in .There he comes . Then you can do what I told you .

sp.speaker: Helgi
sp.p: Anything amiss ? The master seemed cross .

sp.speaker: Indridi
sp.p: That 's nothing .

sp.speaker: Helgi
sp.p: Is Sølvi gone ?

sp.speaker: Indridi
sp.p: Yes . Let 's get through with this . You go into the storehouse and take the things as I hand them to you .

div.stage: They carry the breadstuffs into the storehouse .

sp.speaker: Einar appears in the door of the smithy
sp.p: Einar . H 'm , I feel I 'm getting old . There was a time when I could forge three nails in one heating , and now it 's a hard rub getting through with one .

sp.speaker: Indridi
sp.p: We can n't be young more than once .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: And we can n't cast the slough of old age , as they could once upon a time .

sp.speaker: Indridi
sp.p: Would you care to ?

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: I do n't know . I almost think these new times are not for me .

sp.speaker: Frida
sp.p: Einar , I was to call you to breakfast .Runs against Sveinungi , who is coming out .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: There , there ! Why , you have brought it all under cover and the ropes in the shed . That 's fine . Now , Helgi , when you have eaten , you can go and begin to cut turf . The others will join you when they have had their sleep .Lowering his voice .Einar , will you ask Ljot to come out ? I want to have a little talk with her .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: Einar and Frida go in .I will .

div.stage: Sveinungi locks the drying-shed and looks into the storehouse , pretending to be very busy .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: Here I am , father .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: I did not hear you .Smiles .You step as lightly as a young foal . You are not hurt at what I said a moment ago ? It was only for your own good . I wo n't have any shiftless straggler around here making eyes at you . The parish can gossip about something else .Ljot goes to the fence , resting her hands on it .But that was not what I wanted to talk to you about .Goes to her .You know Arne , the farmer at Skrida . You have seen his son Halfdan . What do you think of him ?

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: I have seen him only a few times .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: There are two brothers . The older one is married and is going to take the farm , but Halfdan is most like his father . You should see the way their place is kept . Their yard is nearly as big as this , and there are long stretches where the grass stands so high that it falls over . It 's as fine a sight as I have ever seen . We stopped there , Jorunn and I , for a full hour , on our way back from town , and there was no lack of welcome . Can you guess what we talked about ?

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: laughsYou can n't ? Arne asked me whether I would have his son Halfdan for a son-in-law .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: And what did you say ?

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: I said I had nothing against it — quite the contrary . I should be content if you had a husband like him , and we are getting old , your mother and I . We do n't know when death may strike us . It may come at any time , and I should like to see the man who is to take my place when I am gone .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: I do n't think you are getting old .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Oh , yes , I feel it . Sometimes when I want to use this or that for my work I find that I have clean forgotten where I put it . That could never have happened when I was young ; there was not a thing that slipped my mind . But what do you say , Ljot ? Your mother thinks as I do , so it lies solely with you whether you will accept this happiness or not .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: I do n't think I care for that happiness .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: You should weigh your words well before you speak . Perhaps you fancy there will be a wooer like Halfdan coming every day . But you do n't mean that ; you only mean that he must come and speak for himself .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: I am so young , father .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: You are past nineteen . There are many girls who marry at seventeen , and you have been so well taught that you can readily take your place at the head of a household . I need not be ashamed of you there , that 's sure . And you will have your mother near you , for it is understood , of course , that you and Halfdan stay here with us . You will have your bridal now in the fall , and next spring you can take over the farm .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: But I scarcely know him at all !

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Your mother did not know me , and I can n't see but that we two have lived happily together all these years . It is not always those who marry for what they call love who are happiest . Arne and I are friends from old times , and I have as good as given him my word .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: straightening herselfYou should not have done that without speaking to me .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Goes in .What has come over you ? Do you mean to go right against the will of your parents ? I can tell you one thing , if it is this tramp you are thinking of , it shall never come to pass . Not as long as I live .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: Your father was angry . What were you talking about ?

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: He wants me to marry a man I do n't know .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: Does he ? You cannot say of Halfdan that he is a man you do n't know .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: We have never spoken a word to each other .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: Yet he has been here several times . Once he stayed overnight . Besides you have heard him spoken of , and you know his people . Everybody knows the Hofstad people .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: Father has given his word without asking me . He had no right to do that .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: You have worked yourself up , Ljot . I do n't understand you . Can it really be that you have promised yourself to some one without letting your parents know it ?

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: I have not .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: You need not hide anything from me . If you have given your word , you must keep it .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: I told you that I have not .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: You could not tell your old mother a falsehood ! But if you are free and not bound by any promise , this puzzles me . Halfdan is young and a capable man , and his father is one of the richest and most respected farmers in the countryside .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: But I do n't care for him . You can n't mean that I should marry a man I do n't care for .Leans over the fence .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: Once you are married you will come to care for him .Goes to her .It is a great step you are about to take . Weigh your words well , so that you may not rue them . Be careful not to thrust away happiness when she reaches out her hand to you , or there may come a day when you will repent . You must know that your parents wish nothing but what is good for you .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: with tears in her voiceIt seems to me you are against me , both you and father .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: stroking her hairI believe you are hiding something from your mother . I think I know what it is . You were very much pleased with the bird 's skin you got to-day .Ljot is silent .The winter your father asked me in marriage there came to my home a man who used to go from farm to farm doing odd carpenter jobs . One evening I carried his coffee to him where he was at work . He had a big chest standing there that he kept his tools in . I can remember it plainly ; it was yellow . I stood waiting for him to finish his coffee so that I could take the cup back , when he took out of the chest a work-box — the prettiest thing I 've ever seen . It was of dark brown wood , the lid round , with pictures of animals carved on it . He made me a present of it , and when I was about to go , he asked me for a kiss , but I would not give it to him .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: You never told me about this .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: He was a good-looking man , with big brown eyes . Well , when your father came , my father and mother both wanted me to become his wife . It was not altogether easy for me , but I would not go against their wishes . I thought it my duty to please them , and besides the other man had never asked me straight out .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: But he was the one you cared for .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: Perhaps I thought so at the time .Silence .He went away on the night he heard that I was promised to your father . A year after I married your father , he was drowned — some thought he had taken his own life .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: Maybe that was your doing .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: How can you say such a thing to your mother !

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: Do n't be angry with me , mother .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: A man who cannot bear his fate is not worth much . I should not have been happy as his wife , and I could not wish for a better man than your father . When two people live together a whole lifetime and have an honest will to do what is right by each other , they will come to care for each other , as the years go by .Silence .I have told you this so that you may think it over , but if you feel in your own heart that it is right to go against the wishes of your parents , then you will have to do so .Ljot is silent .You say nothing , my child ? I have tried as best I could , in my poor way , to do what seemed my duty . I cannot give my daughter any other or better advice . When the hour of sorrow comes , as it must come to you too , there is nothing else that can bring you peace .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: I will do as you wish .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: I always knew that I had a good daughter .Strokes her hair .Goes in .How glad your father will be ! This will be a great day for him , and you will never regret that you did as your parents wished .

div.stage: Enter Einar and Frida from the house .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: to FridaThey go into the smithy .You can start the bellows . I hope the fire has not gone out .

div.stage: Enter Helgi from the house . He goes into the smithy and comes out again with a turf-spade in his hand .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: in the doorShall you be home for dinner ?

sp.speaker: Helgi
sp.p: Exit to the left .No , the others will bring it to me .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Are you here ? Wo n't you come in and talk to your father ?Patting her shoulder .They go in .This is the happiest day in my life since the time I got your mother .

div.stage: Enter Jakobina with a plate of chicken-feed in her hand ; goes to the door of the smithy .

sp.speaker: Jakobina
sp.p: Is Frida there ? Can you spare her while she runs over to the chickens for me with their food ?

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: Frida goes with the chicken-feed .Yes , indeed . Jakobinasits down on the horse-blockI had such a queer dream last night . I thought I was standing out there in the yard , and I saw a giant come striding across the hraun . I saw him stop right there — he stood with arms stretched out and bent down over the house .

div.head: ACT II

stage.stage: A grass-grown yard , some rocks partly sunk in the ground . In the foreground , farthest to the right , a tent . In the background , to the left , the farm-house . In the outskirts of the yard a sheep-house with the roof and part of the walls in ruins . Beyond it , the “ hraun , ” a lava-field stretching for miles , studded with jutting rocks and lava formations .

sp.speaker: It is evening of the same day

lg.l: Not reach up to heaven , pray ?

div.stage: They cover their eyes in prayer . Silence .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
