sp.p: uncovers her eyesThe peace of God be with us .The Servants rise and shake hands .Jorunnpatting Frida 's cheekNow you must not be afraid of the earthquake any more . When we trust in Him , no harm can befall us .Gathers the hymn-books .Please take the books back to the tent , Ljot ; it 's a little too early yet to go in .Ljot goes with the books .And you may fetch the shoes I was sewing . I left them in there .

div.stage: Some sit on the rocks , others squat in the grass . Only Sveinungi remains standing .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: coming from the tentHere are the shoes , mother .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: Thank you , daughter .

div.stage: Ljot lies down in the grass , gazing out over the “ hraun . ”

sp.speaker: Indridi
sp.p: Did you hear the church-bells ringing ?

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: I did not hear them .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: I did . They rang of themselves .

sp.speaker: Indridi
sp.p: Where were you , Thora , when the shock came ?

sp.speaker: Thora
sp.p: In the kitchen .

sp.speaker: Indridi
sp.p: It 's your week , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: Thora
sp.p: I do n't know how I ever got out , for the whole floor heaved under me , so that I was thrown right against the wall , and you should have seen me when I came out — all black from the falling soot .

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: And the rest of you — where were you ?

sp.speaker: Bjørg
sp.p: We were sitting in the badstofa , sorting wool .

sp.speaker: Rannveig
sp.p: It felt as if some one was shaking the roof and trying to pull up the whole house .

sp.speaker: Indridi
sp.p: We were just about to leave our work and run home to hear how you had fared , but then I thought they would be sure to send us wordlooking askance at Sveinungiif anything had happened . Besides , we wanted to get enough turf cut while we were at it so that we should not have to go back another time .

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: But I must say that when I began working again , it went against me . It was like cutting into a living thing — like skinning a live animal .

sp.speaker: Rannveig
sp.p: Ugh , yes .

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: And the place where we 'd cut turf last year looked like an ugly scar .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: Did you meet anybody when you came home from work ?

sp.speaker: Indridi
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: And no outsider has been here this afternoon . They do n't come when they are wanted . I ought to have sent one of you to the next farm to find out how things were there , anyway .

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: I can easily go yet , if mistress wants me to .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: Oh , no , it 's getting late . I hope we shall have no bad tidings from any one .

sp.speaker: Indridi
sp.p: I hope so , too .

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: I 'm afraid the Vik farm-house has fallen . It is both old and poorly built — nothing like ours .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: You should have seen the hawks , Jorunn , right after the shock . They kept flying back and forth , just as they do when they 're warding off a foe from their nest .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: They were frightened .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: And no wonder . Great pieces of rock came tumbling down into the creek . The sheep out on the heath yonder huddled together in flocks , looking like old snow .

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: Then you were out hunting .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: No , I was not hunting . I was looking at the hawks , wondering whether one could get at them by going down in a rope .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: What about the boy , Sveinungi ? Do you mean to let him stay with the sheep all night ?

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Certainly . He can sleep to-morrow .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: I was only thinking he might be afraid to be alone .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: He 's no more afraid than grown people .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: I saw he took both the dogs with him .

sp.speaker: Helgi
sp.p: There was a man walking across the hraun a little while ago . Who can it be ?

sp.speaker: Indridi
sp.p: I saw him too .

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: It was Sølvi . He carried his gun .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: How still it is on the hraun .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: I thought you were listening for something , while you lay there quiet as a mouse . I thought you were listening for the earthquake .

sp.speaker: Frida
sp.p: Can one hear the earthquake when it is coming ?

sp.speaker: Rannveig
sp.p: Are you afraid ? Yes , sometimes it can be heard a little before the shock . They say it sounds like the clatter of hoofs from many hundred horses .

sp.speaker: Bjørg
sp.p: To me it sounded like the whistling of the wind .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: You should sit down , Sveinungi . You 'll get tired standing .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: I am not tired .

sp.speaker: Frida
sp.p: What if the earth should open up right here where we are sitting ?

sp.speaker: Rannveig
sp.p: It wo n't . Who told you that it might ?

sp.speaker: Frida
sp.p: Jakobina said so .

sp.speaker: Rannveig
sp.p: You must not listen to all she says ; she talks so much .

sp.speaker: Jakobina
sp.p: I say nothing but what is true . At the time of the last great earthquake the ground cracked and made a fissure many miles long ; I saw it myself . The earth opened her mouth to breathe .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: to FridaDo n't be afraid . I have a black lamb — do you remember it ?— with white feet . When I get it home in the fall , I will give it to you . Jakobinafacing the “ hraun ”Not one of you knows the hraun as I do . Can you tell me why the hollows out there are never filled with snow ? Have you ever seen the snow falling fast enough to cover even the rims around them ? It 's the earth blowing her breath against it . The earth sets traps for men ; the earth is a man-eater .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: to JakobinaYou must not frighten the child .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Was n't it you , Jakobina , who said that sometimes blood comes on the window-panes ? It bodes ill , they say .

sp.speaker: Jakobina
sp.p: Why do you ask ? There is no one here who has seen it , is there ?

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Never mind why I ask .

sp.speaker: Jakobina
sp.p: Well , if I must say it , it is a sign that some one in the house is going to die soon .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Or it might bode ill to the farm itself , maybe .

sp.speaker: Jakobina
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: That it might be doomed .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: Indeed , it means neither the one nor the other . It 's nothing but a silly old superstition .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Not that I believe in it , but look at the windows . Do n't they look as if they were wet with blood ?

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: It 's the sun shining on them .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: And see the gables , how white they are . They do n't look whiter from the fields down yonder when you spread a cloth over them to call me home .

sp.speaker: Indridi
sp.p: lowering his voiceDid you see the sheep-cot fall ?

sp.speaker: Thora
sp.p: Yes , it happened just as we came out .

sp.speaker: Indridi
sp.p: What did Sveinungi say ?

sp.speaker: Thora
sp.p: He said nothing .

sp.speaker: Indridi
sp.p: But he told us to move out here .

sp.speaker: Thora
sp.p: No , it was Jorunn who made us do it .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: to JorunnI did not tell you that when I came into the badstofa , right after the shock , our old clock had stopped running .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: Was it broken ?

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: No , when I touched the pendulum it started again , but the place was still as death when I entered . The grass on the roof cast a shadow over the skylight . It was as quiet as when my father lay dead .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: I think we had better go and lie down . There 's nothing gained by staying here any longer .

lg.l: I can n't see that there was any need of moving out , but you had your way ,

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: I feel sure that they have done the same on all the other farms . We must be thankful it is summer , so that we can stay outdoors .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Must we be thankful ? So you give thanks that my work is ruined .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: We must take what comes , whether good or evil , and trouble may help us to remember all the things we have neglected to give thanks for .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: I do n't know but that I have always done my duty . I have built all the sheep-cots ; I have fenced in the land and looked after it as best I could . I demand justice of Him up there .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: risingI wo n't listen to such talk . Did you buy the land from Him , perhaps ? And what did you have to pay with that was not His already ?

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: You need n't mock me . You can walk all over the yard and cut your handful of grass with your scissors wherever you like ; it grows thick as wool everywhere , and it 's all my work .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: Goes into the tent .Was it you who ruled the hraun for thousands of years so that it did not swallow up the bit of ground you are standing on , which you call yours ?

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Which I call mine !Stamping his foot .It is mine ! I 've bought the land from Him up there with my work .

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: I believe the worst is over and that we shall be let off with the fright .

sp.speaker: Indridi
sp.p: I hope so .

sp.speaker: Bjørg
sp.p: You can never tell . Remember what happened the time when more than three-score farm-houses fell in one night .

sp.speaker: Thora
sp.p: It must have been dreadful .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Now you must all go into the tent .

sp.speaker: Jakobina
sp.p: Goes into the tent .I should n't wonder if something dreadful were to happen to the farm .

div.stage: Sveinungi stands quite still a little while , then walks a few steps , pauses , takes a few more steps , and again stops .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: Are you not coming , father ? Mother told me to ask you to come in .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Why does n't she lie down ? She need not wait for me .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: We are so frightened , father — all of us .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: It 's getting cold .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: Yes , it is cold .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: The sun has set .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Why are you coming out again , Jorunn ? Ca n't you sleep ?

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: No , I can n't sleep .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Do you remember the night you thought I was lost in the snowstorm ? A light was burning in the upper window . To see it was better than meeting a human being , and when the dogs began to bark behind the door , it was just as if the house itself were speaking — calling out its joy . It sounded better to me than a human voice , and when I stepped into the hall , the darkness seemed to put its arms around me . Never have I had so sweet a welcome , not even when my daughter was a little child .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: Ought we not to go in , Sveinungi ? It 's getting late . You too must go in now , Ljot .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: I am only waiting for father .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: Do you hear that , Sveinungi ? Ljot is waiting for you , and the servants can n't sleep either before you go in .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: I am not going to stay in the tent to-night . I am going home .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: You do n't mean that !

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: But , father dear !

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: I wo n't let any foolish fear drive me out of my house , and it is nothing but a foolish fear . The earthquake will not come so suddenly but that I shall have time to get out . It 's impossible . Besides , the badstofa will hold . It 's well built , though it 's old .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: Do you think the badstofa will hold if there should come a big earthquake ? You cannot mean that !

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: It is not at all sure there will be another shock . It 's only a fancy that the earthquake must needs keep on once it has begun . I believe it is over ; I feel it .During the last speeches the Servants have been coming out of the tent .What are you running out for ? Go in , all of you .

sp.speaker: Jakobina
sp.p: I must tell master about the dream I had . It was last night . I thought I was standing out in the yard and saw a giant coming across the hraun . He walked with long , unsteady stridesshe takes a few steps forward ; her voice sounds distant and threatening, and seemed to grope as if he were blind . Then I saw him standing right by the house — with arms stretched out ; he bent down over the farm and stood there like a stone cross .Makes the sign of the cross with her arms .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Did I ask you to tell me about your dream ?

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: I beg of you , Sveinungi , that you do not stay at the house to-night . It would be tempting God .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: It 's rather He who is tempting me . If I ran away , it would serve me right to have the house fall down .Pointing to the house .Sveinungi walks homeward .There it has stood waiting for me every evening as far back as I can remember . I have seen the windows flaming in the sun . I have seen them wet with rain . I have seen them white with frost . I 've been with it ever since I was a child . I have climbed on the roof as I climbed on my father 's shoulders . When I stood on the ridge , it seemed it had lifted me up to let me see better . No , Jorunn , even if I knew the earthquake to be coming , I should go home . Nor is it any wonder that I long to get into my own bed . I am old now , and I have waked up there almost every morning of my life . I have gone to bed so tired and worn that I could barely stand on my feet and have waked up young and strong . I have been ill and have lain there watching the sunbeams flitting across the floor .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: Are you going home ?Following him hurriedly .Whatever happens , your fate shall be mine .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: stops and looks backDo you hear that ? She is not afraid , my wife .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: How can you do it , father ?Walks a few steps away from the others and remains standing there .

sp.speaker: Jakobina
sp.p: Goes into the tent .God be with you , Jorunn , and with you , Sveinungi . You have been good to me , these nineteen years .

sp.speaker: Helgi
sp.p: There , they went in .

sp.speaker: Bjørg
sp.p: Yes , they are in there now .

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: I think we had better go and lie down , since there is nothing we can do .

sp.speaker: Indridi
sp.p: No , we can do nothing .

sp.speaker: Thora
sp.p: It will be a long night .

sp.speaker: Rannveig
sp.p: Poor Ljot !

div.stage: The Servants walk slowly into the tent .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: goes to LjotI wish I could make you happy as easily now as when you were a little girl .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: struggling with her tearsFather does not care for me at all . He does not think of me for a moment .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: Your father cares for you , no doubt of that , but he is beside himself with the earthquake .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: You do n't know what I am talking about .In sudden fear .If only something dreadful does not happen !

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: We must trust to the Lord to keep us all . Wo n't you too try to lie down ?

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: I can n't sleep .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: Goes into the tent .Perhaps you would rather stay here a little while . Let me bring a shawl for you ; it is getting cold .

div.stage: Ljot stands motionless looking out over the “ hraun . ”

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: coming from the tentThey are asleep in there already . Wo n't you put the shawl around your shoulders ?

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: I am not cold .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: Then I 'll spread it over one of the rocks for you to sit on . They are wet with dew .Spreads it over the stone .There ! What did you have in mind when you stood there looking out over the hraun ?

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: I was thinking of an old tale Jakobina once told me . It was about a young girl . She went out on the hraun with bare feet to meet her sweetheart , and wherever she stepped the moss grew under her foot .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: That 's a pretty story . I can tell you one too , if you care to hear it . It might help to quiet you a little .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: takes his handYou are so good .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: sits down ; relatesIn olden times , they say , there was an underground stream that ran straight through the country from south to north and was meant as a sign of truce between land and sea . It happened that a cross-eyed , ill-natured shark was trying to tempt a young whale to swim that stream from end to end . The whale 's name was Spray-tail . He was the handsomest of all the young whales and could shoot three jets of water at once . The shark boasted that he had swum through the stream himself , but of course it was only real fishes that could do it . Spray-tail felt stung on behalf of his kin , and as the shark had told him that there were openings here and there in the roof of this underground way , he made up his mind to try his luck , trusting that he could hold his breath from one opening to another . But it fell out otherwise . Spray-tail never came back . The last ever heard of him was that some swans , in their flight over the hills , had seen a jet of blood spurting out of the ground . The whales were in a rage and , as they thought in their grief that the land had broken truce , they goaded the sea to wreak vengeance upon it . Are you listening ?Ljot nods her head .One night a dreadful storm broke . The sea came rushing in over the land , fell upon the rocks like a monster , and tore them to pieces . The next morning thousands of sea fowls ’ nests were wrecked , and where green fields had been there were black sands . Now there was sore need of wise counsel . A shrewd old raven said that the fire should be roused . All the birds agreed that the raven had spoken well , but none dared do the deed . The raven was made judge , and decided that the spider should undertake the ticklish task , and that the eagle should carry her to the crater . They gave the spider ten fat blue-flies to take with her . She spun herself well and firmly under some strong feathers , and off they went . They flew over deep dales , over dreary wastes , and over glaciers . In the evening they came to the fire-mountain , and there they rested overnight , but they did not sleep much , for the fire was snoring like a giant down below in the earth . Early the next morning the eagle flew to the top of the mountain . The spider made fast her thread and spun herself slowly down into the crater . It was dark down there , and the heat and sulphur made her eyes smart , but she could see enough to make out that the fire lay sleeping under a very thin black coverlet . The spider knew nothing but the finger-language , and she moved her legs incessantly , telling fully and truly all about the havoc that was wrought , and urging the fire to come to the rescue lest the whole land be swallowed up by the sea . Yet the fire did not stir . Then the spider bent her legs up under her and let herself fall all the way down to the fire . She stretched out one leg and poked the black coverlet . From that moment she could n't remember anything till she was lying at the rim of the crater again . She peeped down and saw that the fire had thrown off the coverlet and was red and blazing . Then the spider understood that her task was done . Everybody knows how the fire had its reckoning with the sea and filled up whole fjords with lava and ashes .

div.stage: Sølvi is seen approaching from the “ hraun . ”

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: risingYou must tell me that story over again some time . I could not listen rightly .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: risingWho is that coming so late ?Looking .Now I know him ; it 's Sølvi .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: I saw him a while ago walking over the hraun .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: He may bring us news .

div.stage: Enter Sølvi carrying a gun and with a game-bag on his back .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: Good evening .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: Good evening .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: How good it seems to meet people ! You have moved out , of course ?

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: You are walking late .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: You will have to take the earthquake as my excuse . This has been a bad day . What has happened here at your place ?

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: One of the outbuildings came down and a part of the yard-fence .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: At Hol one wall of the house fell . The folks barely got out .Lays down his gun .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: Was anybody hurt ?

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: No . I could not stay there any longer . I saw your house standing , and that was a relief .Looking at Ljot .Yet I had to come .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: What do you think ? Do you believe the earthquake is over ?

div.stage: Sølvi fails to answer ; looks at Ljot .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: My father and mother are sleeping in the house .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: Why in the world are they doing that !

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: We were ready to go to bed , but father would not come into the tent . Mother begged him to stay , but it was no use , and when father went back to the house , mother went with him .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: But the buildings may fall at any moment if there should be another shock .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: Sveinungi knows that as well as we do , but he would not let the house stand forsaken .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: We must hope that no harm will come to them . So that is why you are still up . Have the others been in bed long ?

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: No , they went in a little while ago .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: May I look at your gun ?

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: As much as you like .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: Is it loaded ?

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: It is .To Ljot .You are not angry with me for coming so late ? It seemed an eternity till Sunday .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: I knew you would come .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: You knew it ! Wo n't you sit down ? I have something to show you .Ljot sits down . Sølvi opens the game-bag ; takes from it a large fern .I found this out on the hraun . Is it not beautiful ?Sits down .Look , the stem is no thicker than a hair , while the leaf can easily hide your whole face .Holds it up before her face .It trembles when your breath touches it .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: You have pulled it up by the roots . May I have the moss that came with it ?Sølvi loosens the moss from the roots . Ljot lays it in her hand ; smiles .When it withers , I 'll keep it in my shoes .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: Will you keep it in your shoes ? See these two small ferns on one root . They look like two slim hands .Looks at Ljot .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: puts the gun asideIt 's a fine one . It must have cost a good deal . Perhaps you bought it yourself abroad ?

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: I did .Lays down the fern . To Ljot .If you have time , you can plant it to-morrow . It wo n't hurt it to lie overnight in the wet grass .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: goes to SølviHow long were you abroad ?

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: Seven years .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: That 's a long time .Sits down .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: My father was angry with me for keeping your bird 's skin .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: Was he ? And I was thinking of asking you to visit me at Hol some time before I leave .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: I hardly think I dare to .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: You could take Einar with you . It is not much more than an hour 's ride , and I have a number of things I should like to show you ,— petrified tree-trunks that I have dug out of the earth , in which you can see plainly every bud and shoot , and stone slabs with impressions of flowers and leaves that lived thousands of years ago . Should you like to see them ?

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: I should like it ever so much .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: I have some rocks , too , baked by fire and furrowed by ice . If you knew all the tales they tell me ! They lay bare to me things that are hidden from every one else .

div.stage: A whirring of wings is heard far away .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: stands up , pointing with his fingerLook , there is a flock of ducks flying over the hraun .Stands gazing .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: in a low voiceIt made me so happy to see you . This evening , when the sun was setting , I reached out toward it . I did the same when I saw you .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: They 're flying unusually low . There they alight — I 'll get my gun .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: risingI 'll lend you mine .Hands him the gun .It will carry a distance of a hundred and thirty feet .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: What size shot have you ?

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: Duck-shot .

lg.l: Ljot , you do n't mind , do you ? I shall not be gone long . If they rise ,

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: goes to herMy star must be in the heavens to-night .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: You must not think that I was sitting up so late because I was waiting for you — I saw you walking over the hraun — but we sha n't talk about that .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: Shall I tell you why I came home from abroad ? It was for your sake .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: sits downThat is not true .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: sits downOne night , the last winter I was away , I must have been dreaming , but it seemed to me that I was awake . I had come back home and was walking on the hraun . The hraun was covered with ashes . As I walked , I suddenly fell into a deep cleft and kept on falling and falling . At last I found myself lying on the bottom , unable to stir . Death came and sucked the life out of my eyes and held it in her hand like a tiny flame . Suddenly a woman stood beside me dressed in moss . She pleaded for me so long that death gave her my life . She looked like you . It was you . Do n't you know that you hold my life in your hands ?

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: I think I shall go in . It is hard to tell when Einar will be back . When he is out hunting he forgets everything .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: I love you , Ljot ! You have not been out of my thoughts since the first time I saw you . Everything reminds me of you — the sun , the sky —

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: I too have been happy in seeing you and talking with you .Stands still as death .This morning , right after you had gone , my father told me that on his way home from town he had seen his old friend ,— and my father wanted me to promise myself to the son of his old friend , but I would not , because I was thinking of you . Then my mother came and talked to me — and I gave in . I could not do anything else .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: Why did I not speak before ! You wo n't feel hurt at what I say , Ljot ? You must not let your parents decide your life . That is for you to do .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: You do n't know my father . If he thought I was standing here talking to you , I can n't tell what he would do .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: I am convinced your parents have but one wish , and that is for your happiness .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: I do n't know . My mother does not say much about happiness ; she does her duty — and I know mine .Turns toward the tent .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: Are you going ?

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: It is better that we two should not meet again — it would only cause us suffering .Moves away .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: following herYou do n't realize what you are about to do ! You will be committing a terrible crime — against all the wonderful days that life meant us two to have together . For you do care for me , Ljot , do n't you ?Ljot is silent .I thought you cared for me . When you spoke to me this morning you blushed , and I thought it was your heart that gave me its promise . The joy of it overwhelmed me .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: It matters little whom I care for . I have given my word .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: You think it is your duty to keep your word , but there is another duty that is far greater , and that is to open your arms to happiness when it comes . There is no greater duty . It is the meaning of our existence . You must feel that , you who have grown like a flower out of the earth !

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: It is not only that I have given my word . If I had neither father nor mother , I should break my promise , but I know that it would grieve my parents . This morning father said to me that it was the happiest day of his life since he got my mother , and I know it was true .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: You must tell your parents that you cannot keep your word . You must do it for my sake .Kneeling .You are the only one I care for in all the world .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: I can n't deal such a blow to my father . No other living being has been so good to me as my father .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: risingYou do not care for me at all .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: You think it is easy for me !With tears in her eyes .I own a spring — I cleanse it every Saturday . I have told it your name .Goes to the tent .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: You are going !Turns away from Ljot , sits down on one of the rocks , covers his face .Ljotstands silent for a long time , then goes over to him and takes his hands from his face

p.stage: Sølvi takes her face between his hands and kisses her .

sp.speaker: Jakobina
sp.p: coming slowly from the tentWe are not all asleep in there .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: holding Ljot by the handLet us go out on the hraun and look for Einar . Ljotruns to Jakobina , puts her arms around Jakobina 's neck and holds her closeI know that you care for me .Goes to Sølvi and takes his hand .Come !

div.stage: Jakobina stands still , following them with her eyes , then shakes her head and turns toward the tent .

div.head: ACT III

stage.stage: The farm-house is in ruins . Only the farther side of the “ badstofa ” is standing . It looks like a dark cavern . The servants have gathered near the wreckage ; they are bare-headed , the men in their shirt-sleeves . Sveinungi is standing near the dark opening .

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: peering into the gloomI do n't know . There 's only one post that holds the roof , and it may snap at any moment .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: It wo n't . It is drift-timber , which never rots .

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: And besides , it stands aslant ; the slightest push would make it go with a crash , and there would be no getting out alive if the heavy roof came down .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: You are afraid . Is there anybody else who dares ?

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: You cannot ask any man to go in there .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: to JonIt would take you but a moment to bring out those few things . There 's my tall chest — you know where it stands — and my old clock ; you can unscrew it from the wall with your knife .

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: I am not going in there .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Get drunk and brag — that you know how to do , all of you .Starts into the ruins .

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: Is master going in there ?

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Do you think I will let my things be ruined , because you are a coward ?

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: Then I will go with you . It 's easier for two .

div.stage: Sveinungi and Jon disappear from view .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: No matter what happens to that man , he will never learn to bend .Goes to the ruins ; looks in .Can you see anything in there ? Is it not too dark ?

sp.speaker: Sveinungi and Jon appear , carrying the tall chest
sp.p: Sveinungi . Indridi and you , Helgi , come here and take it from us . Set it over there .

sp.speaker: Indridi
sp.p: to Jorunn , as the men carry the chest out into the openCan we leave it here ?

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: Yes .She peers into the ruins again .Enter Jakobina from the direction of the tent . Jakobinagoes to Jorunn , lays her hand on Jorunn 's shoulderI must feel that you are indeed safe and sound .Stroking her arm .When you went home , I was afraid that you would never come out of that house again . I thought your husband must be struck with blindness .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: You do n't know where Einar and Ljot have gone ?

sp.speaker: Jakobina
sp.p: I saw Ljot going out on the hraun .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi and Jon appear , carrying the clock
sp.p: Sveinungi . You will have to be a little careful , the glass is broken .Steps out into the open . To Jon .I dare say you have had enough of this .

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: I can n't say it was any too cheerful in there .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: to the menYou can carry the clock into the tent ; the dampness here might be bad for it . And you , Bjørg , go and get a blanket to spread over the chest .

div.stage: Exeunt Servants , Bjørn running , Indridi and Helgi carrying the clock , Jakobina following them .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: You are lucky , Sveinungi , that you have not come to grief with your foolhardiness .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: It is nothing but my duty to care as best I can for what is mine . I have risked my life before in a good deal worse dangers than this . But I must send some one to look after the boy . He may have lost all the sheep . Will you go , Jon ?

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: I will .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: You had better drive the sheep home .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: And if you should see Ljot and Einar , tell them to hurry .

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: Exit .I will .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Where are they ?

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: They are out on the hraun .

sp.speaker: Bjørg
sp.p: Here is the blanket .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Why did they go out there ?Takes the blanket , goes to the chest , and runs his hand over it .Here it 's been bruised .Throws the blanket over it .I did not think you would have all this to go through .Takes a long breath .It is pretty hard when one has grown as old as I am to see one 's work destroyed .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: That is true .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: My only comfort is that I shall have a capable man to help me put up the buildings again .Gazing over the “ hraun . ”What can it be that is keeping Ljot out there ? Has she been gone long ?

sp.speaker: Rannveig
sp.p: I do n't know .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: I hope she has not gone down into one of the fissures . One can n't tell what may happen . The walls might cave in , or they might close overhead .

div.stage: Enter Indridi from the direction of the tent .

sp.speaker: Indridi
sp.p: Einar and Ljot are coming now . We could see them from the tent .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Are they coming ?Goes toward the background .Yes , Ljot has seen us ; she is running .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: She must have thought we were buried under the ruins .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: lookingThere is a third person with them . Who can it be ?

sp.speaker: Rannveig
sp.p: So there is .

sp.speaker: Indridi
sp.p: I believe it 's Sølvi .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: What business has he out there at night ?

sp.speaker: Indridi
sp.p: It 's hard to tell !

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: I do hope that Ljot has not been talking to that fellow .

div.stage: Enter Helgi from the direction of the tent .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: puts her arms around her motherI was so frightened !

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: Were you frightened ? You are quite out of breath with running .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: smilingAnd have you no greeting for your father ?

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: Dear , dear father !Embraces him .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: You were glad when you saw us ?

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: I was so glad that I do n't know yet what I am saying . I was afraid you had been caught under the ruins . I thought that was to be my punishment .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: stroking her hairHave you done anything you should be punished for ?

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: taking his handBe fond of me , father ! Be very , very fond of me !

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: Thank God , you are safe ! Then you had time to get out ?

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: No , we were in there .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: Were you in there ?Goes to the ruins .How weird it looks !

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: goes to the ruinsIt is only the one post that holds it all . If that had snapped , you would never have laid eyes on us again .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: looks into the ruinsIt 's a miracle it did n't break .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: Yes , if it had not been God 's will , we should not be here now .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: turns from the ruinsIt was not any too cheerful out on the hraun either . The place seemed suddenly to have become alive .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: What in the world made you go out there ?

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: There was a flock of ducks flying over the hraun , and I wanted to try a shot at them .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: to LjotAnd why did you go with him ?

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: I was not with him . Sølvi and I stayed behind .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Do you sit alone with a stranger in the middle of the night ?To Sølvi .And you , why are you here at this time ? I will not have you go hunting on my land without asking my leave .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: I was not hunting on your land .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: But you are picking up stones , and I forbid you to take as much as a single pebble from my land . Now you know that .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: Why do you say that , father ?

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: You can go into the tent , Ljot . You have nothing to do here .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: I have something to say to you .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: What is it ?Ljot is silent . To the Servants .You can go . To-morrow I shall have a talk with you , Einar , which you will remember .

sp.speaker: Einar
sp.p: It was not my fault .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: to the ServantsExeunt Servants .Go ! What are you waiting for ?

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: to LjotNow , what is it you have to say to me ?

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: I have come here to ask for the hand of your daughter .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Has not my daughter told you that she is betrothed ?

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: I have told him everything . I never cared for Halfdan — you know that , father , and I will not be his wife .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: Ljot , it has never happened yet that one of my kin has broken faith . If you do it , you will be the first .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: And you have not reckoned with your father . It does not lie altogether with yourself to break your word . Do you think you can make a fool of me ?To Sølvi .It does not make you my son-in-law that you have trifled with my daughter .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: It was no mere chance that we two found each other . Only for Ljot 's sake have I stayed so long in these parts . I came here to-night to find out how you had fared ; I could not help it .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: You feel proud that you have coaxed a young girl to break her word . You think yourself very brave , and you have taken advantage of her when she was beside herself with fear . You have come like a thief in the dead of night .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: I love your daughter . There is nothing wrong in that , and I am proud and happy that she has given me her heart .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: to LjotSo that is what you have done . I dare say you have met him before and more than once behind my back .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: Not once .

lg.l: And straightway you are ready to break your word . You knew that
Halfdan 's father is the best friend I have .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: You must forgive me , father !

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: And you knew I had sent him word that everything was settled .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: takes his handDo you remember , father , when I was so little that I had to put my arms around your knee ? Then you never said no when I asked you for anything . I am still your little girl .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Let me go !

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: You do care for me , father . I know of no one who has been so good to me as you . You have given me everything that I call my own . You must give me my happiness !

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Let go my hand !

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: I understand that Sølvi is very dear to you , my child , but this comes upon us unawares , and it has been a terrible night for us all .To Sølvi .Could you not have waited before speaking to Sveinungi ?

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: I cannot help it that it has come in this way . I would have waited if I could .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: I might perhaps have seen my way to put in a good word for you two .To Sveinungi .You wo n't be hard on your daughter ! If we had been lying under the ruins now , she would have had no need to ask us . To-night we must not be merciless .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Who is this man ? I do n't know him , nor do I know his people .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: My father was a farmer like yourself . Had he been living , you two might have become friends .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: interruptingThe only thing I know about you is that you go about picking up stones like the children .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: You speak slightingly of my stones , but the knowledge I gain from them can bring me more money than you ever made on your farm , and it can bring me fame .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: What kind of knowledge is that ?

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: Those stones teach me to know my country and how it has been built by fire and water and ice . They give me an opportunity of finding out new links in laws that are eternal and mightier than all mankind .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Indeed ! Since you are so passing wise , you ought to have told me days ago that a great earthquake would come to-night . That I could have understood ; but it seems that you knew as little there as the rest of us . I believe old Jakobina is wiser than you .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: I do n't know how wise she is , but I do know of people who go through life as if they were blind . They may have been living in the same place all their lives , and yet they have never seen the landscape they live with — neither its beauty nor its peculiar character .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: They have n't ?Points toward the “ hraun . ”I have been out there in a snowstorm so heavy that I could scarcely see a hand before me , and shall I tell you how I found my way ? I knew where I was by feeling before me with my hands .Laughs .No , I have never seen the hraun !

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: I did not say that you were among the blind , and I am sure you are human enough not to force your daughter to marry against her will . It would not give you much joy to feel that you had made her unhappy for her whole life . If you think you do not know me well enough , you can find out all you wish from myself or from others .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: I have no desire to learn anything about you , and you need not worry about my daughter . She will stay here with me .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: Ljot is not a child any longer . She can decide for herself .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Perhaps you think she can n't live without you .To Ljot .If you care as much for him as he imagines , I will let you prove it . I will let you choose between him and me . If you choose him , then I have no daughter any more .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: You do n't mean to force me to such a choice !

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Can you for a single moment be in doubt about whom to choose of us two — him or your old father ?

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: kneelingHe is so unutterably dear to me .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Get up ! I do n't want to see you lying like a dog at my feet .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: risingThen you have no daughter .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: I knew you would not fail me !

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: You had better give your consent , Sveinungi , since it cannot be otherwise . I cannot do without my only child .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: goes to LjotYou are quite free , Ljot ; I will not try to force you , but when you have thought it over , you will not leave your father and mother for the sake of a stranger . You are my only child , and you have been the light of my eyes since you were a little tot . When I came home from work I was never too tired to listen to what you had to say . When you stroked my cheek it was like warm summer rain falling on my face . It will be lonely and empty here if you go . You cannot do it .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: Father , it is you who drive me away .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: You must listen to me . It has always been my intention that you should take the farm , and yesterday when you promised to marry Halfdan it seemed to me that all my wishes had been fulfilled . I was happy , and not only for your sake , but fully as much for the farm . Yet you would leave it now in the midst of misfortune . Look about you ! Not a single building is standing . Can you let your old father sit here alone and forsaken ? You might as well kill your father . And for whom should I build it up again if you are not to have it ? It might as well be left to rot on the ground .

sp.speaker: Ljot
sp.p: You do n't know , father , how much I care for him . I used to dream often that the mountains fell so that I could see the land beyond . To-night it seemed to me that the mountains fell .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: You are a wilful girl .To Sølvi .Could you think of taking over my farm , perhaps ?

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: I could not —

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: interruptingDo you two believe that you can cow me ?Pointing to the ruins .There is a chest of drawers in there that Ljot keeps her clothes in . I will have nothing of hers in my house .To Sølvi .Will you go in there with me and bring it out ?

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: I have nothing to do in there .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: You can go , Ljot . I can n't bear to see you .Goes over to the ruins ; stands resting his hands on the walls .

sp.speaker: Sølvi
sp.p: takes Ljot by the hand quietlyExeunt .It is better that we leave your parents alone for a little while .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: You will have to give your consent , Sveinungi . You say yourself that all you have done has been for your daughter . Sveinungiturns to Jorunn , passing his earth-stained hand over his foreheadDid you understand what I was about to do ? I wanted to get him into the ruins , and then I meant to give the post a shove .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: God forgive you , man !

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Now we two must hold together . If we two are of one mind , I believe Ljot will give in . You must try to bring her to her senses .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: They are very fond of each other . It warmed my heart to see them . It brought back the days of my own youth . I feel sure it would be a sin to try to part those two .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: And you say that !

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: I think it was her fate to meet this man . She has always been a good and dutiful daughter .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: And it was you who went with me into the house ! Have you turned against me — you too ?

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: goes to himYou must not make the evil worse than it really is . The man looks as if he came of good people , and we have every reason to believe that he is a capable man . Even if we can n't keep Ljot here , as we had hoped to do , she will certainly find time to come and see us once in a while , and we shall have that to look forward to .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: You think only of your daughter . It is nothing to you if my life-work is wasted . I could name you many farms that have been an ornament to the neighborhood as long as they have been handed down from man to man in the same family , but once they have passed into other hands , they have been tended in a makeshift way or left to go to rack and ruin altogether . You have seen those old forlorn places , where the site is overgrown with grass , and the heather has been allowed to spread all over the yard . They remind me of graves . I tell you the truth : if such a fate were in store for my farm , I should wish for nothing but to be lying under the ruins myself .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: Who says that your farm will not be rebuilt ! You are not so old that you cannot do it without help . If I know you rightly , you always grow younger and stronger whenever there is anything that needs all your powers . In a year or two you will have the buildings up again every bit as fine as before .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Spare your wheedling ! What would be the use , even though I got the houses up again ? When my days are over , everything will pass into the hands of careless people . And to think that this should happen only because of a fleeting fancy !

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: Did it seem to you like a passing whim when Ljot was begging for your consent ? To me it seemed that she was pleading for her life .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Even though this should mean more to my daughter than I think it does , that can alter nothing . It is my right to care for my home and keep it intact even after I am gone . When I am standing out in the hraun and looking toward home , the green yard looks like a spot of sunshine .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: You take it for granted that none of your kin will ever reap the benefit of your work , but your daughter is not dead , though she has chosen another man than the one you wanted her to marry . Why should not those two have children ? They are both strong and healthy , and there is , after all , a chance that some day one of their sons may take over the farm .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: I dare say a son of his would be the right man !

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: A daughter 's son is often more like his grandfather than his father . You know that as well as I .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: You are like a child playing with soap-bubbles . When one breaks , you are straightway ready to blow a new one . You can n't make me play at that game . Even though they should have children , do I know how they would turn out ? And you see it the same way yourself , but you are trying to fool me into giving my consent .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: What do you gain even if you have your way and part those two ? You may bring it about that your daughter becomes one of those sour old maids ; for you cannot mean to drag her to the altar against her will .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: I did n't expect you to be against me . You would n't mind leaving the farm , if you could live with your daughter . You care more for her than for me .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: her voice growing huskyWhy do you say this , Sveinungi ? I have never weighed my feelings for you two , nor do I intend to do it . I only know that where you are , there I stay too .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Even this very earth upon my hand is dear to me . I care for it as the old house-leek would if she could feel . As for the young man whom you think so much of , I should have grudged him even to have the earth fall on his face . But you were not born here , as I was . You have not lived here as a child . You are an outsider .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: Am I an outsider ! I am grown too old to kneel before you as your daughter did , but if you send her away , I know that even though you build your house both larger and finer , the room will seem less light to me , and the smile will be gone from my face . Can you not spare me the sorrow of losing my only child ?

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: I thought you knew me well enough not to tease me with bootless prayers . What I have said stands .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: I do n't know what gives you the right to be so heartless . You were tempting God when you went into the house , but He had mercy on you and spared your life , and the very first thing you do is an act of cruelty .Bursts out sobbing .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Do n't take to crying , wife . Jorunnweeping ; sits down on one of the stones that have been torn from the wall by the earthquakeI do n't see how I am going to live through it if you send her away .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: stands puzzled for a moment , then goes to herI understand that you take this very much to heart . Do go into the tent now and lie down . We must try to get over this as best we can .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: risingI am sure I have lost my daughter forever .Weeps .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: takes her hands and kisses her on the cheekI have always said good night to you with a kiss . You have been a good wife to me . I little thought , when you went with me into the house , that you should cry yourself to sleep this very night because of me .Jorunn clings to him , weeping . Sveinungi releases himself suddenly .Listen to what I say . You shall not leave me this way . Now you can go to the young folks and tell them that I give my consent .Moves a little away .But it will be on one strict condition .Jorunn wipes her eyes on her apron .They must promise me that if they have a son , he shall be brought up here with us .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: her face lighting upI believe this thought was sent you by Him who showed mercy upon you this night .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Even if it should be their only child .Goes to Jorunn .And you can tell them that it is only for your sake I yield . Now you wo n't cry any more ?

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: God bless you ! How happy Ljot will be !Turns to go .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: You need n't be in such a hurry . I do n't care to have the young folks see that you have been crying . And one thing more ; Sølvi must not come here until I send him word . I want to explain to my old friend how all this has come about .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: Sølvi will understand .Sits down , very still , with her hands in her lap , gazing straight before her .And the boy is to be named Sveinungi .Unconsciously she passes her right hand back and forth over the edge of the stones .

sp.speaker: Sveinungi
sp.p: Yes , they can well be used again , the old stones . Now you had better go to Ljot .

sp.speaker: Jorunn
sp.p: rising , pats his armExit .Yes , yes , I am going , and I am happy .

div.stage: Sveinungi stands for a moment looking after her , then bends down over the stones , examining them closely . He turns over one stone — and one more —
